PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister tell the Australian people whether the Prime Minister still believes that the Fairfax journalists are `out of control'. Is it not a fact that the Fairfax journalists are more in control than the Prime Minister's communications minister, Senator Alston—better known as doormat—given Senator Alston's total failure to persuade the coalition's backbench committee of the political benefits of cross‐media ownership changes? Will the Prime Minister apologise to the board of Fairfax for the various destabilising and undermining comments he has made about their performance, now that he is `comfortable and relaxed' about Fairfax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Prime Minister has said is that there are other matters of higher priority before the government. I would have thought that Labor would agree with that.

ANSWER.PARA: What I found fascinating was what Mr Gareth Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, said today. He said the media was `sufficiently concentrated'. That is as a result of Labor's policies and is not surprising. Just let us look for a short while at Labor's record on this matter.

Who allowed the takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, which resulted in one company owning nearly 70 per cent of newspapers in Australia? Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Who allowed TV audience reach rules to be expanded from 43 per cent to 75 per cent? Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Who allowed the number of regional TV stations to shrink dramatically? The Labor Party—Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

Madam President, do you remember what Senator Button was reported to have said? You do, Senator Schacht, do you? Of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on media policy at cabinet, Senator Button said, `Tell us'—the cabinet—`what your mates want?' That is the way the Labor Party ran media policy in this country: `Tell us what your mates want, and we will deliver, and the result will be greater concentration'—as was demonstrated by what Mr Evans said.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of interjection is far too high.

—The whole record of Labor was one of intervening in media policy for Labor's mates. And the result of that—the bottom line—was greater concentration in the Australian media. So what right has Senator Schacht got to come into this place and complain of others? We were interested in sound policy but decided that there were other matters of higher priority. That should be something that Labor applauds not condemns.

ANSWER.PARA: I could go on with all the quotes from Mr Keating. Do you remember what Max Suich said on Labor's record in relation to media intervention? Do you remember Mr Keating's threat to Black? He said, `If there is any notion that you show bias'—that is, that you barrack for the coalition—`then there is no way you would qualify to be the kind of owner we would like.'

That was Mr Keating. That was Labor's record in relation to media policy. The Labor Party has no record to stand on, and that was confirmed today by Mr Evans. My advice, Senator Schacht, on the basis of your record would be: let the coalition get on with the important issues facing this nation, the issues of helping small business to grow and employ and of giving back more to families, as we did with our tax policies. That will be something to be recognised and applauded by all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Prime Minister has wasted 14 months trying to change the policy and has now adopted a position that is the Labor Party policy on media from the previous government—so they are not changing anything—and given that the Prime Minister now totally runs communications policy, is he giving thought to taking over ministerial responsibility for the Department of Communications and the Arts and reappointing his current minister to a less arduous portfolio such as tourism, which is an area the minister has focused on extensively since his appointment?

—Nobody is saying that there is a policy that cannot be improved; it can be improved. Most of Labor's policies can be improved. What the coalition is saying is that there are major issues on the agenda—taxation policy, for example. There are priorities that can result in a reduction of income tax—to the benefit of all Australians. As I said in answer to the primary question, the fact that the government would choose to concentrate on the priorities that are of greatest importance to the Australian people is something that ought to be applauded rather than condemned.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, the Keating government over four years increased taxes by 30 per cent, borrowed an additional $70 billion, sold off $9 billion worth of assets, spent the lot of that, then left us with a $10 billion deficit. Minister, the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the ACTU have suggested that government expenditure should be massively increased. What would be the impact of this on the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Gibson, for the important question. We have seen some very clear statements in recent days from the Democrats, the Labor Party and the ACTU. They can be summed up in the sense that the Labor Party have learned nothing from their 13 years in government and neither, it seems, have the Democrats or the ACTU. The sorts of policies that the Democrats, the Labor Party and the ACTU are promoting are big spending policies which, as we know, lead to high deficits, high taxes and high debts, and do not create real jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, you may be aware that the Democrats released a paper entitled `Res toring Confidence', which I suggest would be better titled `A Confidence Trick'. This paper proposes a massive $2.5 billion fiscal stimulus, the majority of which would be through higher spending. This higher spending was quickly endorsed by the embattled shadow Treasurer and Mr Kim Beazley. And the ACTU, back to their old tricks, showing just how out of touch they are, called for even more spending. As the Treasurer said, they are like bees to a honey pot.

Madam President, let me make a couple of points clear which hopefully will throw these claims for higher spending into some perspective. First, if big deficit spending created real jobs, Labor would have licked the unemployment problem—which they did not. Of course, they spent up big, and unemployment got worse. We can all remember—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was going down under us; it is going up under you.
—Senator Sherry, I am very glad you interrupted because most of us can remember—particularly a lot of families out there, small business and people in rural areas—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is too high.
—Most of us can remember the recession we had to have. Remember the recession we had to have?

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp, just wait for a moment. The level of noise in the chamber is unacceptably high.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was just thanking Senator Sherry for the interjection. We are able to remind ourselves that Labor's policies did not create growth; they created huge debts, huge taxes and, among other things, the recession we had to have—the architect of which was Captain Wacky himself.

ANSWER.PARA: We know that the government at the end of this term, through its policies, will show a surplus in its budget. This is a surplus which this government has created through its own hard work—a surplus which has been created, I might say, despite the efforts of the Labor Party and despite the efforts of the Democrats.

This is where the hypocrisy, I believe, comes in. They oppose the government, regrettably, at every turn to cut spending. They have opposed the government on the tough decisions. They seem to be under the illusion that, now the government has done the hard work—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are tough, Rod—attacking the Democrats!

—Certainly tougher than you, Robert. We have seen how tough you are, Robert, on those hard decisions—retired, hurt; Robert Ray retired, hurt. That is the score. Just to refresh our memories, I will give a few examples of how Labor opposed the measures that we brought into effect to rein in—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise is again far too high.
—It is pathetic.
—Order!
—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Cook calls out—one of the many failed Keating ministers on the front bench. He has never apologised for the deficit you left.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not stay on the front bench, Robert; you went to the back bench. At least they showed some shame.
—Senator Kemp, direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you, Madam President, but I am being provoked from the other side. The Labor Party has opposed the government at every turn to cut back on the massive deficit that the Labor Party left us. They opposed the fiscal consolidation measures we had to take. They opposed the sale of Telstra. They opposed a whole raft of measures.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say, the prospective surplus that we have is this government's surplus. It is a surplus that this government created. Let me make it clear: it is not a surplus which Labor or the Democrats could have achieved. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, should we be using taxpayers' future incomes to give a big spending boost to the economy now, as suggested by these groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —We can get some clues as to what some of these groups hope to achieve through the release of the paper by the Democrats. It works off a false premise that we have a flat economy, with poor growth prospects. The GDP growth is forecast to accelerate this year to 3¼ per cent, building on the step up of growth in the first half of 1997. Inflation is continuing to be low, and unemployment is expected to fall. Of course, this view is generally endorsed by private sector forecasts. The growth is supported by five cuts in interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, you are from a high interest rate party, and you have always opposed cuts in interest rates. But we are a low interest rate government, and we have been able to deliver something which you could never deliver. (Time expired) .
—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts.
—Do you mean the doormat?
—Yes.
—Senator Carr!

—That is Minister Doormat to you, Senator Carr. Minister, when did the Prime Minister first inform you that he had decided not to proceed with the changes to Australia's cross‐media ownership laws? How did he inform you of the decision? Did he phone you, write to you or send a member of staff around to tell you? Has the Prime Minister finally informed you of the outcome of his discussions with the Murdochs at Kirribilli House in August? Can you inform the Senate whether there was any correlation between the government's decision on this matter and the unprecedented visit by the Murdoch team to the Prime Minister's sickbed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that Senator Faulkner had the courage to ask this question. I can well understand why Senator Schacht was once again wanting to hide from it. I would not normally go into detail of this nature, but I will say for Senator Faulkner's benefit that the decision was taken yesterday by cabinet. Let me do even better and tell you why cabinet took the decision. They took it because they well understood that the Australian public was interested in the real issues.

ANSWER.PARA: In other words, we were not going to play the distraction game. We were not going to fall for the sort of nonsense that we have been seeing on the other side of the chamber. What we have seen in recent months on this issue is the Labor Party, through Senator Schacht, saying, `We'll refer any legislation that comes up to a Senate committee. We'll have a full inquiry but, despite that, we are going to oppose it. We are not going to countenance any change in the rules, irrespective of the merits.' This was said by Mr Beazley, Mr Evans and Senator Schacht. In other words, they wanted to have their negative little piece of cake and eat it. What they wanted to do—and Senator Schacht was no doubt salivating at the prospect—was have a wall to wall, all star celebrity cast so Senator Schacht could have his 15 minutes of fame before a Senate committee; so he could be basking in the glory of pontificating, hectoring, lecturing and telling all these media moguls how the world ought to operate according to him. All that that would have done was give Senator Schacht one last chance. The trouble is that Senator Schacht blew it last week.

You asked about meeting with the Murdochs, and that is very relevant. You know what happened last week? Senator Schacht could not be bothered coming into question time because he went to see Lachlan Murdoch. What he did was have a confidential conversation. How long did it remain confidential? Only as long as it took Senator Schacht to blurt out all the confidential details all over page three of the Financial Review. You have blown it. They will not talk to you again. They will not take your calls. They are sick to death of it. You cannot behave in that way.

We were not going to allow you to have that sort of ridiculous charade or play those sorts of games. The extraordinary thing is that Senator Schacht, after putting out of all sorts of irrelevant press releases, put out another one yesterday saying, `This government has no policy process other than the delivery of deals to a particular media proprietor to curry political favour.' If ever there was an outfit that turned private deals into an art form, it has to be this crowd. What we have is the absolute chutzpah of getting up and basically saying what you saw when you looked into the mirror: `We were the ones who specialised in this and we're outraged because we think you might be doing the same thing.' The fact is that we were not, and Senator Kernot said as much this morning.

Let us be absolutely clear: we were not going to play this little game. We want to concentrate on jobs. We know what the public are interested in. The public are not interested in seeing you grandstanding. They do not want to see legislation bogged down for months by people who have no interest in the main game. We are interested in the main game. We are more interested in addressing unemployment and comprehensive tax reform. Senator Kernot is showing you the way. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I heard Senator Alston explain to the Senate that this decision was taken by cabinet yesterday. Minister, perhaps you can explain why on 29 June you said on Channel Seven's Face to Face program that you would put the cross-media rule changes `into the form of a draft bill, introduce it into parliament in the next session and hopefully get it through before the end of this calendar year'. Minister, we want to know why you did not have the guts, as the Prime Minister's doormat, to front up to a doorstop here in Parliament House yesterday and explain your actions—explain how you were comprehensively humiliated and rolled by the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit rich. I think all of us remember the Sydney Morning Herald and that classic headline `The Minister for Getting Rolled'. This is the one bloke in the history of the parliament who started his submission with the words, `I know I'm going to get rolled but'. Why would you serve it up? Presumably the only reason you serve up that sort of nonsense is that you want to be able to go back to the pre‐selection convention and say to the far Left, `Well, I did my best. I knew I was going to get kicked in the teeth.'
—That is important.

—It is important. That is precisely it, whereas we are interested in real policy. The tragedy is that, instead of Labor focusing on the issues, what Senator Schacht did was spend last Friday trying to get a kick of the football. Not only did he put one out of bounds on the full, but when one of my blokes tried to line him up, when he saw him between the ball and himself, just as he ran in Senator Schacht fell over. I said, `Don't worry, son, he does that to us all the time. He always falls over before you can land a punch on him.'(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I ask—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of breach of the standing orders is appalling. Senator Crane, would you start again.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I ask: is the government aware of recent reports of a decline in union membership? In particular I ask: to what extent have the government's workplace reforms, with their emphasis—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Crane. Senators on my left will cease interjecting. Senator Crane, would you start again? I could not hear what you were saying.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I ask: is the government aware of recent reports of a decline in union membership? In particular I ask: to what extent have the government's workplace reforms, with their emphasis on freedom of association and freedom of choice for employees and employers, encouraged unions to reassess the way they operate and who they associate with?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Well may senators opposite laugh. The fact is that, as a result of the Workplace Relations Act, the unions are required to provide statistics and information that demonstrate the level of membership. What do the latest figures show? They show that over the last two years the 20 biggest unions have suffered a net membership decline of over 86,000 members. This is truly appalling, because this crowd actually spent millions of dollars on a membership drive committed to increasing membership levels by over 200,000 by 30 June this year. In football parlance, that is almost a 300,000 turnaround and you cannot have a worse vote of no confidence than that.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very serious issue for the country and quite clearly we will obviously have to take advice from a wide range of areas. The declining significance of the union movement makes it much more difficult of course to get any sensible idea of what the various unions think. I would have to say that I think the New South Wales approach has been consistently a much more sensible one than that—to engage in constructive dialogue, to encourage the workers, to boost their levels of productivity and to cooperate with employers.

But no. What do we find? Once again they have their head in the sand. Yesterday Bill Kelty briefly addressed the congress and, instead of getting up there and giving a decent apology, what did he do? He tried to change the subject. He said, `We have a new strategy. We are going to concentrate on the regions.' I do not know whether he read our regional arts policy, but quite clearly this is not what the membership wanted to hear. They wanted to know why all those millions of dollars have been absolutely down the drain and why the membership—the rank and file—have been voting with their Nikes. They are not just walking away; they are running away in droves and they are doing it because they know that you are just not focusing on the real issues.

The tragedy of course is that the union movement is not entirely irrelevant. It is still functions very effectively as a pre‐selection convention. Those of you who go to the estimates committees or watch them on television would have seen Senators Collins and Mackay in there last night. They were very diligent—

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw you asleep.

—No. I was wide awake. I was absolutely transfixed, because their knowledge of the Workplace Relations Act was very impressive. Why do they do it? It has nothing to do with solving the problems of Australia; it has everything to do with being able to go back and say, `I did my best. I went through it all. I delivered. I understand how important it is. Please vote for me next time.'

ANSWER.PARA: That is not solving the problems of Australia. What the public really want is unions that are relevant and not unions that are spending millions of dollars on basically funding delegates to run around the countryside trying to wage phoney political wars. They want you to get into the productivity game. They do not want to see two-thirds of the Senate on that side of chamber at the beck and call of an organisation of declining influence.

What do we find? The latest solution is that they have released some form of special retail card. I will tell you of a big opportunity. Senator Kernot is going along there on Wednesday to address the congress. It is your big chance to tell them how to get relevant. Tell them not to keep sending along people like this. Tell them to get into productivity. Tell them to concentrate on looking at the benefits for workers, not for those who want to live off the earnings and eventually progress through to the Senate chamber. Tell them to actually try and look at what the Australian public and a real work force are interested in. That is the only way you will arrest the decline.

If they keep going the way they are, you can talk to yourselves as much as you like, but it will not make any difference at all to the ordinary workers. They will simply treat you the way they are now as utterly irrelevant.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is it not a fact that you have failed to deliver a full and open public inquiry on cross-media ownership, as you promised? Is it not also a fact that you reneged on your promise to maintain funding to the ABC in real terms? And is it not also true that you broke your commitment that you would introduce a draft bill on media rules into the Senate in the current sittings and have it passed by the end of this calendar year? Minister, can you confirm that after these humiliating failures you have requested or have been offered the job of Australia's High Commissioner to London following the retirement of Dr Blewett?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very impressed that the opposition is in a position to make those sorts of offers, but I have to say I respectfully decline the invitation because there are even more important things to be attended to here. Senator Schacht no doubt is indebted to Senator Evans for asking the question he did not have the courage to ask—in other words, to get up and basically read out his press release.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is—and you would know if you had been paying attention—that in about September or October, I think, last year we went to Perth for cabinet. As a result of that, we made a very high profile, public announcement that we were going to conduct the inquiry into the cross‐media rules via the department. It has been out there for almost 12 months. I do not recall anyone getting up and complaining about it then.
Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it went through to the keeper, as it always does with poor old Schachtie. He was probably still drafting his ABC submission and missed it. The fact is we made it very clear that we thought there was a more effective way of proceeding—and we did it. It was conducted internally.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left and it is totally disorderly.

—The second part—I know you would not want me to be irrelevant—of Senator Evans's question was, `Why did you break your promise to maintain funding in real terms to the ABC?' I thought we had gone over this ad nauseam. As I recall it, what we said was that we would maintain current levels of funding. I must have given you this lecture half a dozen times, so take notes. What I said consistently was that that applied for the period of that current triennium and that is why we did not make the $55 million reduction operative in the last financial year. It applied only once the triennium had finished.

ANSWER.PARA: So, you understand, we maintain current levels of funding for that triennium. Otherwise, of course, it is meaningless. What you would be saying is we could never at any stage in the future—even though we might be in government for 20 or 30 years—make any change to funding levels. And that is not right, as you well know. You would have been in like Flynn if you had half a chance to make cuts to make the ABC more efficient and effective, and that is what has happened, in fact. They did manage to identify very quickly very significant ways of finding about $28 million as a result of the One ABC policy—and that was very much consistent with the announcement we made. So there is no question of having broken a commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—You can say `rubbish' as much as you like. You will have much more time to do it, Senator Collins. I am sure you will enjoy yourself up there on the back bench. It was very good of you to come back now that the territory election is finished. But, the fact is that if you go back and look at what we said before the election, you will find the policy made it absolutely clear we were going to maintain current levels of funding. I cannot remember whether there was anything else in the question, but that will have to do, I am afraid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am intrigued by the suggestion that the Prime Minister would allow the minister to do something important. Minister, did you, at any time during the two trips you made to London in the past six months, discuss with any Australian official the possibility of your appointment to the High Commissioner's post?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of breach of standing orders today is persistent and, by some senators, wilful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a place for false modesty, so I do not want to go into great detail. Basically, I get a lot of these offers as I travel around the world. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday, the minister answered this question in some detail and I am disappointed that he is not able to take this further. May I ask at the same time: is it not true that your government's policies favour multinational companies and have seriously damaged our local IT industry? When will you put in place real measures to support Australian jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

I can assure you that we have policies in place to boost employment and they cover a wide range of areas, not just this particular part of policy making. In all sorts of respects, the tough decisions we have had to take have been very much made against the background of the need to get inflation under control, to get interest rates down, to make the economy more competitive and to create the opportunity for new jobs. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, are you aware that commercial airline pilots have indicated that they will not fly into Port Hedland, Alice Springs, Hobart or Launceston airports if Airspace 2000, the new Australian airspace plan developed by a group led by Dick Smith, is implemented because they consider it unsafe? Can you confirm that if appropriate radar facilities were installed at these locations, the class E airspace may be acceptable to pilots? Can you advise the Senate how much it would cost to install these facilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot provide the level of detail that Senator McKiernan is seeking.
—What do you do for a living?

—I basically read the briefs, add to them a bit and respond when I am asked. What I can say is that Dick Smith was invited by the chief executive of Airservices Australia, Bill Pollard, to put forward a proposal on the future management of Australian airspace in June 1996. This resulted in a draft proposal—a plan for the future management of Australian airspace, Airspace 2000—which was released for industry comment in August 1996. I am advised that Airservices has consulted extensively with industry on the draft proposal, receiving and giving careful consideration to comments from various aviation interests.

ANSWER.PARA: On 25 March this year the board of Airservices Australia endorsed Airspace 2000. This is a significant change for the management of Australia's airspace and will provide the aviation industry with the opportunity to gain full advantage from a safe, flexible and efficient airspace system with substantial savings for the industry.

Implementation of Airspace 2000 is planned to commence on 4 December this year but is subject to the satisfactory outcome of an independent audit of the safety case by an external, independent and internationally recognised authority in air safety management and, most importantly, approval by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

In considering the Airservices safety case, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority set up an expert panel, including Airservices Australia and industry, to consider the outstanding issues, culminating in the release of a notice of proposed rule making which seeks industry comments on proposed changes to regulations required by the Airspace 2000 proposal. Industry representatives on the panel covered a broad spectrum of interests—for example, regional airline pilots, 747, 767 and A‐300 pilots, air traffic controllers, a sports aviation representative, a flying instructor and a representative from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. CASA is expecting this process to be resolved by 22 September 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, would you agree with the managing director and chief pilot of Par Avion, Don Wells, who was reported on the front page of last Wednesday's Hobart Mercury newspaper as having said that `it was a matter of when—not if—there would be an accident at Launceston or Hobart' if Airspace 2000 is implemented. Will the minister guarantee that the government will do nothing that will reduce the safety to Tasmania's airspace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what was on the front page of last Wednesday's Hobart Mercury but I can assure you that the government and, indeed, all of those responsible for air safety, are very conscious of the need to ensure that all airports measure up to appropriate safety standards. Quite clearly, if those remarks were made by someone of significance, they would need to be taken into account by all of the relevant authorities. I assume that that has happened but I will make further inquiries for you and ascertain whether they have a specific response.

ANSWER.PARA: The way you expressed it is one person's view; you would expect that there are a lot of others who have an alternative view. No-one is going to be out there recommending unsafe procedures. It would not be the first time in history that someone has played the card by fundamentally disagreeing with the majority. It is therefore a matter that I would hope is being properly taken into account. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. It follows the death of Princess Diana this week. I refer to the question I asked on 10 October last year about the harassment of the Princess by the global press through a story which turned out to be as false as it was scandalous. You said at the time, Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: It is really not a matter for the Australian government to have a view on that sort of behaviour.
In light of the tragic events of this week, is it still not a matter for the government to have a view on behaviour which many world leaders have said requires action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all still reeling with shock from the events of last Sunday morning, our time. I suppose that most of those media reports do suggest that the car in which Princess Diana was travelling was being at least pursued by some freelance photographers. In one report I saw there was even a suggestion that there was a motorcyclist zigzagging in front of the vehicle. Those are clearly matters for the French authorities. They have had seven people in custody for 48 hours. I imagine that they will be pursuing whatever solutions are appropriate. If charges are to be laid, that is a matter for them.

ANSWER.PARA: The wider question is the extent to which it is acceptable in modern society for public figures to be pursued and, in many instances, I suspect, photographed without their knowledge. I have seen suggestions that it may well make sense to say that you should not be able to photograph a person on private property.

In the first instance, it would be very interesting to see the response from the media around the world. I do not think Australia has ever been a significant problem in this regard. So I certainly do not think we should be leading the world in pursuing an appropriate outcome. But I do think it will be of importance to gauge the reaction of the world's media in an endeavour to ensure that nothing like this can happen again and particularly to investigate whether a line ought to be drawn in relation to the privacy of celebrities.

But it does not follow from that that governments ought to be rushing in with a whole new set of privacy laws. In many respects, I think the tragedy of these events may well lead to a measured outcome which would not make it necessary to pursue statutory solutions.

But, as I say, I think we will all be following the events closely. If it is in fact true that the car was being pursued and was travelling at speeds of up to 160 kilometres in order to get away from people who simply would not take no for an answer, then that is certainly unacceptable conduct and we would not condone it in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I recognise the great difficulties in this conflict between freedom of the press and privacy. Will the minister seek to have the government keep in contact with the French and British governments and other governments who are reviewing this matter beyond watching press comment? In light of calls from some Australian personalities about their concern that this phenomenon is beginning to arise in Australia, will the government review moves in other parts of the world in order to come to a better judgment as to where the line does lay between personal privacy and freedom of the press?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Brown is right—a line does have to be drawn. Certainly the government will be doing a lot more than just reading the newspapers on this matter. I expect there will be the relevant contacts that you referred to so that we are in a position to make proper judgements about the appropriate responses in other countries and, if necessary, in our own. If we proceed on that basis we will have a more sensible or more detached view of what is necessary in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Why did Senator Hill mislead the Senate yesterday when he assured Senator Conroy—

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can laugh. Just wait for the reaction of the people who will be on the receiving end of this. Why did Senator Hill mislead the Senate yesterday when he assured Senator Conroy that changes to public sector superannuation will be:

BREAK.PARA: . . . consistent with the promises . . . made by the Prime Minister in the past.

How is cutting in half employer contributions and resulting retirement benefits and the closing of existing Commonwealth public sector funds consistent with the written assurances given by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, not to `cut and destroy superannuation for existing and prospective' public servants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of monumental assumptions in that question—most of them I think are wrong. There is certainly no suggestion of Senator Hill having misled the parliament. What Senator Sherry is doing is feeding off a couple of newspaper articles which, of course—
—We have the cabinet brief.

—Very impressive! I will bet that we do not get any explanation of whether that is desirable in a democracy or whether that is in the best interest of good government. Not a word of it. All we will have is a lot of very smart backslapping and them saying, `How clever we are because we have taken advantage of those who were prepared to basically break the Crimes Act.' In other words, the old philosophy: whatever it takes—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say that Senator Kemp gave you a copy on the side. I would be very surprised. I do not think Senator Kemp would do that because he would probably think you would not be able to read it accurately for a start. More importantly, it reflects enormously on the ethics and standards the other side bring to this debate.

ANSWER.PARA: The articles in the media are wrong in implying that the government intends to slash public servants' superannuation. Any government decision in relation to superannuation will be completely consistent with the Prime Minister's pre-election commitments to public servants—in other words, that the coalition will not cut and destroy public sector superannuation schemes or entitlements.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why are you?
—We are not. Our budget commitment was to allow individuals the flexibility—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure you will get votes. It is about the only sector of the community these days that has any significant level of union membership. So I can understand why you are so concerned about letting them understand how effectively you are protecting their interests. But it just happens to be wrong in this instance.

ANSWER.PARA: Our budget commitment was to allow individuals the flexibility, portability and choice to save for their retirement in a form most suited to their needs. We undertook to examine public servants' superannuation arrangements as part of this commitment. The government is currently considering options in relation to flexibility and choice for public servants. Any decision on the method to be used will be announced at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What about the personally signed letter from the Prime Minister giving a rock solid guarantee not to cut or destroy existing Public Service entitlements in respect of superannuation? While we are on the issue, is it the case that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, failed to give a rock solid guarantee to current and prospective military personnel that their superannuation schemes will also be protected? Can we assume that they will also have their schemes destroyed and their contributions cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose you are changing the subject because you did not like the first part of the answer. We have moved from public servants to the military now have we—utterly unrelated but nonetheless probably fairly typical of the way you approach all of these issues?

ANSWER.PARA: It ought to be quite clear that the Prime Minister's commitment in our election docu ment to not cut and destroy will be absolutely honoured. We will not be going down that track. We will be freeing up the system in a way that you were never prepared to. You were not interested in people having choice because choice is basically anathema. The trouble with choice is that people might go in the other direction.

That has been your problem in all sorts of areas. That is why you do not like voluntary voting, because they might not turn up and vote for you. That is what you are really worried about. In this area as well you use all sorts of reasons why you must force people to be in particular funds, why you know best, why you want to tell them what fund they ought to be in. You are terrified of there actually being flexibility in the system that will allow them to make their own decisions. We believe they are adults, you don't. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, you recently attended the second APEC energy ministers meeting in Canada. Will you advise the Senate what progress was made at that meeting and the implications for Australia? How did Australia stand in relation to the other 17 member economies in progressing the 14 energy principles endorsed at the first APEC energy ministers meeting which you chaired in Sydney 12 months ago?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Troeth very much for that question. It is obvious from the catcalls made by the Labor Party opposite that they really are not interested in the Asia-Pacific region. The second energy ministers meeting was held in Edmonton, and it was made up of the 18 economies in the Asia-Pacific region. There is little doubt that the Asia-Pacific region will continue to be a driver of economic growth as the region's population continues to expand into the next century. Economic growth in APEC is forecast to grow at an average of 3.3 per cent over the next 12 years. This is double what is expected from the OECD. Growth in energy consumption over the period is expected to be 2.2 per cent, as compared with the OECD, at 1.1 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is in a great position to play a major role in meeting the demands of this expansion in the Asia-Pacific region, especially in meeting the accelerating demand for energy infrastructure and energy commodities to fuel this projected growth. There is no doubt this growth in energy demand requires a concerted effort by member economies to ensure the development of efficient and environmentally sound energy infrastructure. The challenge is to ensure that energy is not the bottleneck to growth.

At the Sydney APEC ministers meeting, 14 energy policy principles were adopted. They are aimed at freeing up markets, technical cooperation and mitigation of environmental impact. Reports made at Edmonton by member economies in implementing these principles were in fact very impressive. To some degree it is not surprising, because largely they are market driven. Unless these efficiencies are introduced, unless the markets are opened up, the countries involved will not get the investment, which means they will not get the economic growth.

Australia's progress in these reforms stands up well compared with other APEC partners. Our initiatives in the electricity and gas sectors—removal of export controls on coal, LNG and other minerals except uranium, which I remind the Senate was opposed by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, and action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through the greenhouse challenge program—confirm Australia's commitment to these reforms.
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the interjection of Senator Collins. In my absence I noticed that Mr Beazley said the reason Senator Collins had retired from the frontbench was to go back and look after the Northern Territory. Judging from the results in the Northern Territory election, Bob, it was not a great start. For the benefit of those opposite, these initiatives were well received by the APEC energy ministers and they stand Australia well, particularly in the fiercely competitive market emerging in the race to meet energy demands in the Asia-Pacific region.

ANSWER.PARA: The potential benefits for Australia's electricity industries have been estimated at $5 billion per annum. The removal of export controls represented the removal of a major hurdle to investment and jobs in Australia. Overseas investors no longer need be afraid that a future government will hold them to ransom by misusing export controls—a threat that remains relevant while those controls continue to exist. Those controls merely raise the spectre of sovereign risk and interference in the supply of vital industrial materials, forcing our customers to diversify their sources of supply at Australia's expense. The major focus of the energy ministers was to improve energy efficiency because of the importance of energy efficiency in addressing climate change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, why did the minister for transport, Mr Sharp, personally insist on hiring a consultancy firm headed by former Liberal Party staffer Mr David Trebeck? Why was this not put out to open tender? Can the minister nominate any former Liberal staffer who has not won a government contract yet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be wrong, but I do not recall David Trebeck being a Liberal Party staffer.
—Oh, don't you?

—No. Was he? If he was, say so. He was with the National Farmers Federation. Anyway, I am happy to go back and check that. I thought you had every opportunity to pursue these matters ad nauseam in the estimates committees. I seem to recall you did.
—You were there but asleep.

—I tried to stay awake. I feel it is an obligation to pay attention as much as you can but, when you get this mindless repetition in simply trying to cater for the client back at the ACTU House who wants to know every little detail about every aspect so presumably they can employ more delegates and organisers and spend all those union membership dues on everything except helping the membership, I suppose I might have lost interest at some stage. But I will see what I can do for you.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mackay also asked me about the number of people we have appointed who have not been Liberal Party members. I really think that is a very onerous request. We have a lot of important things to do and to have to spend all the time and trouble compiling a list as long as that would be beyond reasonable demands. But, once again, I will take the question on board and see what we can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I draw the minister's attention to a letter from the participants in the green corps program who claim the scheme has inadequate administration and organisation, unrealistic pay structures, inadequate training of supervisory staff and insufficient screening of sites and work projects. I understand the minister has received a copy of this letter. What is being done about these complaints? Does the minister agree with the claim by one of the participants that they are worse off than if they had been on unemployment benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a letter that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald from a Green Corps participant last week, I understand, complaining about a number of factors which, it was claimed, would have an impact on Green Corps projects. I assume for the moment that is the letter you are referring to.
—The one that I sent to your office, of which I have a copy.

—I will have to check it is exactly the same one in my office, but there is this complaint and I can answer you with respect to that one at least. Complaints from this person were received in June, and I understand that they were vigorously—it has been described to me—pursued by my department. I also understand that my department has continued to monitor that particular project. A DEETYA officer spoke with the participants in July, some eight weeks after the project had commenced, and at that time there were no problems identified with the project.

ANSWER.PARA: Team members were fully aware of the phone number of the DEETYA officer to contact and no issues have been subsequently raised, as I am advised. Complaints about any particular Green Corps program can, of course, be drawn to the attention of my department and the contractor. Team members are all provided with a written statement which identifies contact numbers for both the DEETYA officer and the contractor, Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers. Participants are in fact encouraged to contact those numbers if there is an unresolved problem. Green Corps is, as you know, a new program and we believe that early indications are that it is going to be very successful.

The particular complaint that I am referring to came from a participant in a Green Corps project in the Hunter Valley. It related to payment to that particular participant. I understand that, when interviewed for project placements, all participants were advised of the conditions being offered and that included the rates of allowance that would be paid. The allowances paid are based on the federal national training wage level C, which takes into consideration years of schooling and the age of the participant.

That project commenced in May this year. On 4 June the contractor received a letter signed by some members of the group complaining about the level of allowance and requesting the same level for all participants, and the letter also requested assistance with travel to and from the project site. The DEETYA officer went to the project site and, I think it is fair to say, basically dealt with those particular complainants. There was a change made, as I am advised, to the payment to one participant and the remaining participants, as I understand it, accepted the training wage arrangements. The DEETYA officer agreed to investigate the provision of travel assistance as some participants were in fact having some trouble with that.

BREAK.PARA: I understand that the DEETYA officer went back via mobile phone some four weeks later and was advised that some limited travel assistance had been provided by the CES under the job seeker preparation and support program. The contractor for Green Corps has also written to the New South Wales state government asking for travel concessions for Green Corps members. The contractor has been asked to constantly review the progress of the project to ensure that any problems identified are dealt with very promptly. It is of interest to note that none of the original 10 team members has withdrawn from the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. I also assume that the minister will give an assurance to the Senate that she will continue to monitor the Green Corps participants in the second round in that particular area. Minister, did your department vigorously pursue the complaint in the letter that the participants were told at the commencement of their employment not to approach the media with their concerns? Why were Green Corps participants told not to approach the media? Is it usual for labour market program or other program participants to be given advice like this? Did you actually sanction this particular piece of advice that went to Green Corps participants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that Green Corps participants were in fact advised that. With the greatest respect, I do not take every assertion you put in this place to be true. I will check it out for you.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senator Schacht, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Seantor Faulkner) and Senator Evans today, relating to proposed changes to media ownership laws.

We have seen an extraordinary performance in the Senate today as the government tries to explain its extraordinary backflip over the change on media policy. For 14 months this government tried every device to change the rules on cross‐media ownership in Australia to advantage one particular proprietor. The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, in particular, made statements again and again saying that he would be introducing legislation; he would be negotiating with his own back bench; he would be negotiating with the parties in the Senate; and he would ultimately introduce legislation some time this session. He had the legislation listed on the government's forward program. He made statements in the media in June saying he would be introducing the legislation.

What happened yesterday is that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) cut this minister adrift and left him without any credibility on this issue of media policy. This is not the first time this minister has been cut adrift by the Prime Minister. We now have a minister who has no credibility on media policy. If you were involved in any area of media policy on cross‐ownership rules and you were seeking the views of the government, you would not go to Senator Alston, the minister; you would go to the Prime Minister's office or Mr Costello's office. You would certainly not seek the minister's views because, whatever he said to you, there would be at least a 50‐50 chance of it being rolled over in cabinet or his being told by the Prime Minister to drop it.

Remember that at the last election this minister said he was going to have an open public inquiry into cross‐ownership rules. That was in his own document. In the middle of last year, Costello and Howard told him to drop it, so he had to drop it. Then he said he would have an internal department of communications inquiry to look at it and seek submissions from the media proprietors, but it would not be made public. It still has not been made public.

BREAK.PARA: The only comment he made about that was in the Sydney Morning Herald in a report on 10 February this year when he said the submission from his own department was `pretty tired stuff'. It has not seen the light of day. Since then he has spent endless hours apparently going to the Liberal Party back benchers' committee on media—including National Party members, as I understand—trying to convince them that what he was doing was not a deal specifically for one media proprietor.
Of course, in the end the back bench jacked him up. They would not agree to any particular proposal. Even today the Australian says:
Government MPs have lost count of the number of models Senator Alston has put to them . . .

Despite all those various models he could not convince his back bench. Finally yesterday cabinet woke up to the fact that this man is a paper tiger on policy; that he may not be able to deliver for Kerry Packer, he is certainly upsetting Mr Murdoch and all the other media proprietors, and he is upsetting a whole range of people in the community who are interested in this issue.
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, if you must interject, which is disorderly, would you please at least do it from your seat.

—This minister has been comprehensively rolled by his Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He is the doormat on media policy. He has no standing. I have made no secret of the fact that I have talked to many over the last several months since this minister started the process.

BREAK.PARA: They say here today, `We have dropped this issue. It is not important any more.' But for 15 months this minister went around trying to convince his own party to change the rules. What we have now is a minister who may be alive, who may be breathing, who may be walking, who may be eating and who may even be going to the toilet but one thing is for certain: he is no longer politically alive. He is politically dead because no‐one is going to listen to him any more. Go and talk to John Howard; he treats him as the doormat. This minister is extinct politically. No‐one is going to listen to him. He could not convince his back bench, he could not convince his cabinet, he could not convince the proprietors, he could not convince the community and he could not convince the Senate. He says today, `It would have ended up in a Senate committee,' and that I would have asked some nasty questions. That is what you said today. That was the only defence you had. It is a pathetic defence. This minister is finished. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get a few things straight. If you are a serious player in the game, why are you not asking questions of your opposite number?
—We are asking the Prime Minister, you dope!

—You had the chance to get up today and ask me a question and you did not. I think it is very poor form that you go and see one of Australia's leading media proprietors, you have a private conversation and then you go straight to the Financial Review and blurt it all out. That is disgraceful. Why should they ever confide in you again? It is just appalling. To think that we were worried about Senator Schacht asking nasty questions. What I was worried about was him asking all of these puppy dog questions to show what a great fellow he is; in other words, up there grandstanding to his heart's content, watching people come and go while he presides over it all.

SPEECH.PARA: I had to sit through this years ago. Was I not the deputy chairman and you the chairman of some pay TV inquiry? The witnesses could not get a word in. They had to sit there and be lectured to by some bloke who thought he understood all of the technology. He had not the vaguest idea about it but, no, they had to be polite. You should have heard what they said afterwards. They were absolutely appalled at the prospect of having to come along and put up with that sort of nonsense again.

Let us be perfectly plain: we are the people who are interested in the real issues. We are interested in jobs and we are interested in tax reform. Unfortunately you have turned nega tivism into about the only political approach that you relate to. This is a classic example again: do you remember that article in the Australian about `ordinary people' where Gareth Evans was crying about how irrelevant he had become? They interviewed Senator Schacht and he made this great speech about how those of us in government did not like the cabinet process. What he forgot to point out was that he was not in cabinet. But he went on to say, `We never liked the detail of it. I am much more comfortable with the politics.' He thinks he can have a field day on politics.
I am sorry I was not there last Friday. It would have been very interesting to see Senator Schacht kicking out of bounds after taking a mark in the goal square.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least I tried; you didn't even bother to turn up.

—At least he tried. There you go again. A plea of `guilty'. You tried desperately to get a run in the Financial Review and you did not. You did it at the expense of others and that is not what they are looking for in this industry. They want to be able to have a talk to you privately. They want to be able to express their views. They want you to understand where they are coming from. They know you are a grandstander and that is the last thing they are interested in talking about. What they do understand is that we are addressing the issues of concern and issues of relevance.
—You got rolled.

—No‐one got rolled in this game, my friend. We are interested in the issues that are important. You ask the public; the public do not run around asking you your view. How many letters have you got on the subject?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not get inundated with letters about what proprietors think of me. They are interested in what we are doing for jobs. They say, `After 13 years of that lot my job prospects are ruined. Look what they did. Please do something about it.' They talk about that `ramshackle tax system' and ask that we do something about it. They want us to face up to these real issues. They are absolutely appalled at the thought of someone like Senator Schacht being able to sit up there and pontificate for months on end knowing that, at the end of the day, he has a closed mind and he would be voting down whatever proposal was put up. What is the purpose of going through that sort of charade? There is none at all.

We are not falling for that trap. We are going to concentrate on the main game and we will make sure that people understand just how shallow, negative and backward looking your approach is. That is why you will be comprehensively rejected next time around, because you refuse to make the hard yards. You will not do the policy work. While some of us are beavering away in our offices you are trying to get a kick with the boys. It is all good fun but you are not paid by the taxpayers to do that. You are supposed to be working up media policy. If you do not want to come here and ask me questions, go off and have a private conversation. But don't splurge it all over the newspapers so you can desperately try to deal yourself back into the game. If you are relevant, start asking me questions and I will take you seriously then, but not before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) comes in here and suggests to us that the main game is not media concentration. He comes in here and puts a position which is quite different from the one he has put for the last 10 years. For 10 years the Liberal Party have had a policy to try to grab hold of the media and provide the vehicle by which certain key players get control of that media. It is policy that this government has maintained up until yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Suddenly it is no longer the key or imperative. Why is that the case? Why is there a sudden change in the position being taken by this government? Did it have anything to do with the visit by the Murdochs to the sick bed of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the special arrangement that was entered into there? Did it have to do with the occasion on which the deal with the Packers was thrown out? Those questions remain open.

For 10 years Mr Howard has said that he is a pro market sort of man. He took the posi tion that the cross‐media laws needed to be scrapped. Then suddenly that position has changed. Now the commitment that there would be an open public inquiry into the question of media ownership in this country—a commitment which the government made when in opposition—can equally be scrapped. That is the last thing they would want to hear from the Australian people on such a fundamental question as to who owns and runs the Australian media.

Of course, we have seen a whole range of commitments being scrapped by this government when it no longer suits them. What are they doing? Are they clearing the decks in what they perceive to be the run‐up to an early election? Are they now trying to prepare the ground for an early election where they do not want these sorts of messy issues to be left hanging around?

Is it the case that this policy commitment that they gave—for 10 years they have been committed to it—is suddenly to be scrapped? Is it to be treated the same way that the commitment to maintain funding for the ABC was treated? Will we see the same level of commitment with regard to the public inquiry into media ownership? None of these things matter now to them.

I think that they will find—the backbench will reveal this in due course—that the deal with Packer has been brought undone because Messrs Murdoch senior and junior have put the acid right on this government and have said, `There is a cost to be borne by the oncers in this government if they maintain the sorts of attitudes that Richard Alston and the Prime Minister'—who is now the real minister for media in this country—`have maintained.'

The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, has expressed his deep pleasure at what has happened. The National Party knows the consequences of tying up the regional newspapers in this country in the hands of a few media barons. Channel 10 understands the consequences of being thrown to the wolves by the policies of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and Mr Kroger, who has been acting as the lobbyist for the Packer camp within the senior echelons of this government. They understand the consequences to the National Party when control of the provincial media is seized by these big media moguls. The government ultimately will bear the cost of such a process.

This government now is completely rudderless when it comes to media policy. We have heard a dissertation from this minister about Senator Schacht and what he should be doing on media policy. What is the minister's media policy now? For 10 years he has condemned the cross‐media rules that the Labor Party introduced. For 10 years he has said that they have to be scrapped; they have to be reviewed; they are motivated by revenge; they are anachronistic. What is his policy now? Clearly he does not have one.

That is quite clear from what has happened today. Senator Alston has come into this chamber completely adrift. He quite clearly is the Prime Minister's doormat on all these issues. So it is quite appropriate for Senator Schacht to ask direct questions to the minister representing the real minister for communications—that is, the Prime Minister.

No doubt Mr Packer will be most displeased with the way in which he has been doublecrossed. Mr Packer's press releases showed he was quite clearly committed to the election of the Liberal Party at the last election. He will no doubt express his displeasure in no uncertain terms in the coming months.

For those of you who have yet to find voice on this question, it might be appropriate for you to speak up now to make sure there is a genuine policy which is committed to media diversity in this country, to make sure that all Australians get a fair go and to make sure that our media is not controlled in such a narrow fashion as to squeeze out dissident opinion. You might also learn something about the proper processes that are conducted in these debates. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised by the tone of the opposition on this matter, particularly as it is a matter that is not really a first order issue, a matter that has been around for a very long time and a matter that was of very doubtful parentage under the previous Labor government, which, as I recall it, was out to get the Fairfax organisation when that government set up the cross-media ownership laws.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of creating a media market that is diversified is not new. It was around for a long time under your government. You may have tried to make a fist of it, but it was not a very good one—we still have a very highly concentrated market. It has been a problem obviously not only for Australia but worldwide. Worldwide, countries are trying to grapple with this problem—particularly in highly capital intensive industries like the media, and particularly in small markets like Australia—of how to create a diverse media ownership base.

We in our party certainly have had an enormous amount of debate on this. It has not been ideologically driven, and it has not been driven by particular media proprietors. Probably the major media proprietors today are not too happy with the current situation. I do not think that you can say that we were beholden to them. We certainly were not trying to undertake some measure of revenge on a media organisation like Paul Keating was when he first set up the cross‐media ownership laws.

We have a major problem with media ownership laws in this country, and we do not resile from the fact that the current laws are flawed. We put a priority on what are the important issues in this country at this time. This is not a first‐order issue. It is not an issue which the government should be totally distracted from—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston said it was.

—As Senator Collins, who interjects, realises, the first‐order issue in this country is jobs. What we need is reforms to the system to help get unemployment down. We need to undertake taxation reform. We need to focus on industry policy. We need to focus on native title. These are the first‐order issues facing this country at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: If we had tackled the media issue and gone with the change to the media rules, what would have happened when it came to the Senate? It would have gone off to a Senate inquiry. We would have been held hostage for months by a Senate committee, with people like Senator Schacht grandstanding in front of the inquiry. I have even heard that the Australian Democrats were proposing to subpoena certain witnesses. Senator Schacht could have been in his glory cross-examining Mr Packer, Mr Murdoch and Mr Stokes in such an inquiry. We were not prepared to be held hostage for such a long period on an issue which at this stage is a second‐order issue.

It is an issue which we must come to some resolution on in this country over time. It is very difficult to set down a new set of rules at this point in time. We have just deregulated the media market in this country. As you are moving towards technologies which could involve, for example, one screen which might deliver your newspaper and also your television picture to you, where will that leave Paul Keating's policy of media proprietors being the prince of print or the queen of screen? Fairly obviously with that very rapidly changing technology you have a situation where, with the market moving quickly, with capital moving into this market and with the changes, you could have emerging over time under the current situation perhaps other players in this field and get to a position where we have diversity of media ownership in this country. That is the position we want to move to.

I am amazed that a party like the Labor Party is getting so excited at this time about the fact that we propose to stay with the current cross-ownership media laws which have been proposed, which your party was proposing. Senator Schacht has reaffirmed the opposition's commitment to the retention of existing media rules. Mr Beazley in May reaffirmed Labor's support for the current rules. We have accord on this matter, so what is the big issue? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good point to make is that jobs, health care and education are the things that most Australians are most worried about. But Australians are also very worried about—I do not know why the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) is not getting this input; I certainly am—
—Yes, you do!

—Perhaps I do know why the minister is not getting this input, but I certainly am getting this input. I am being told that Australians are very worried about media diversity in this country. Australians believe that something has been going on that would cut down on media diversity in this country. Why are they worried about that, why are they concerned, why do they think that is the case if this government was always only ever trying to increase diversity of the media ownership in this country? Obviously they are not very well informed, or perhaps they are only too well informed.

BREAK.PARA: If you have a look at all the different plans that were being floated, usually as leaks to different newspaper columnists, for changes to media diversity in this country, you will find that all of those roads led to Rome, that all of those changes to media rules in this country happened to have one outcome. That is what started people worrying. That is what started people thinking that media diversity would in fact go the other way—that we would have a concentration of media ownership in this country. That would have been the outcome of all the leaked plans. I am sure they were not all made up. In fact I am pretty sure that none of them was made up. That would have been the outcome. That is why people are so worried about it.

So what has changed? Why have the government now decided suddenly—and it was very sudden—that this is no longer the case, that in fact they are going to leave the media laws exactly as they are until after the next election? I cannot think of anything, except perhaps two explanations. The first is that they are getting the same sorts of polling results that I have seen, that people are very worried about this. Certainly they are contacting me and telling me that. The second thing is perhaps it has finally occurred to some government ministers that it is really not worth antagonising one major media player in order to help another. Perhaps they were never trying to help one of the major media players, but that is certainly what it looked like and that certainly would have been the effect. If any one of these leaked media plans had in fact come into effect, that would have been what would have happened.

People can be forgiven for believing that there was something in that. I certainly believed there was something in that. I could be wrong—I hope to goodness I am wrong—but it certainly looked to me as if the government had a big problem, they were trying to solve that and they were totally unable to do so. It is very sensible of the government to suddenly dump the whole thing. I think in fact Australians are frightened of it; they are frightened of the cuts to media diversity. That will certainly be to the government's credit if they do not do that.

Let us just have a look at that other question that was mentioned, the one which Senator Alston answered that he had always said that this government would maintain funding for the ABC for only a few months, until the end of the then current triennium of ABC funding. What absolute, complete and utter rubbish. We have all seen that television clip of him being asked about it on the night of the election. He was not even looking for votes then; the whole thing had come in. He was asked, `Will you maintain funding to the ABC?' He said, `Yes.' The next question was, `What if there is this enormous black hole and you do not have the money? Will you maintain funding to the ABC?' The answer was something like, `I am sure the Prime Minister will stick by his promises.' The promise was that funding to the ABC would be maintained.

Go and have a look at Better communications. Go and have a look at your own policies that you put out that said the ABC funding would be maintained. It did not say, `Would be maintained for a couple of months.' That is absolute rubbish; total rubbish. That is completely the opposite of what you told the Australian people before you went to that election, and you did that deliberately. Go and read your own policy. Go and read Better communications. It is a totally outrageous use of policies.

It leads to people not trusting government; you said you wanted people to trust government. It leads to people not believing a word you said. I would be absolutely amazed if anybody believed a word of that at the next election. The whole ABC funding question is one that cannot be defended and should be reversed immediately. I hope that the ALP will say that they will reverse it when they get back into government, and I would be really pleased if the government would also get up and say, `We have seen the light. We realise that we told total untruths to you and now we are going to do the right thing.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. With respect, Senator Abetz has been speaking for four minutes. Surely the speaker on this noting of answers is required to give at least a passing reference to the cross‐media rules of the government?
