That is a very significant increase in the power of the Productivity Commission as compared with the old Industry Commission. We do not believe that is appropriate.

Looking at the Hansard, I see that I advanced some significant arguments yesterday. I do not want to keep the committee unduly in the process of this legislation but I am certainly not convinced of the arguments that were put by Senator Campbell yesterday in opposing the amendment we are dealing with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the functions of the commission and, as I understand it, we are dealing with opposition amendment 2. That details what the functions of the commission are to be:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to hold inquiries and make reports to the Minister in respect of such matters relating to industry development and productivity as are referred to it by the Minister; and
(b) to do anything incidental to those functions.
I would have thought that was a fairly broad remit for the commission, but perhaps the minister would like to address the point that was made by Senator Sherry—and no doubt he will.

I will look at what it is proposed is to be changed, which is in Part 2, clause 6 of the Productivity Commission Bill, headed `Functions of the Commission'. As far as I can see, there may be two or three matters in that proposal by the government which may not be contained within the scope of the opposition's amendments. As I see it, they are (b), (e) and (f).
Subclause (b) of the government's proposal says that the functions of the commission are:
to provide secretariat services and research services to government bodies as directed by the Minister

I can see some merit in that, since the previous commission did provide secretariat services to COAG—I think—and a couple of others. But I would like the minister to explain to the committee why the government believes it would not be possible for that to be done under the Labor Party's amendment. Subclause (e) says:
to undertake, on its own initiative, research about matters relating to industry and productivity

I suppose there is a legitimate fear that, if you let the commission loose to go wherever it likes and to do whatever it likes in regard to industry and productivity matters, you will be letting a tiger out to roam at will. I do not know why the government suggests that this subclause ought to be there, unless it is because it is thinking about the new functions the Productivity Commission will be taking on. I would like to ask the minister and Senator Sherry about that.

In effect, this legislation is doing away with EPAC, BIE and the Industry Commission and putting them all into the Productivity Commission. Subclause (e) means that the functions of the previous bodies will be able to be exercised by the Productivity Commission. That is something that does, on reflection, concern me about the opposition's amendment. That amendment would so confine the commission as to preclude it from performing the functions of EPAC, BIE and so on.

I would like to hear from Senator Sherry on that. If you are going to allow the Productivity Commission to perform those functions, I see that as a problem about that amendment. If the desire was to see the previous functions of those mentioned bodies performed by the Productivity Commission, the amendment by the Labor Party might be too constraining.
In regard to (f), it says the functions of the commission are:
to promote public understanding of matters relating to industry and productivity

The minister might address this question: is that its function? I suppose it can be said that the old productivity department used to do that. We used to have productivity councils and the like that used to promote public understanding in matters relating to industry and productivity. But I would have thought the Productivity Commission's work is fairly well cut out, particularly if you are to allow them to do what is contained in (e), and to enjoin them to do what is contained in (f): to promote public understanding of matters relating to industry and productivity.

I would like the minister to address that. While I am fortunate enough to have on my staff a former very senior officer in the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism—or the Department of Productivity as it was; they changed their names an awful lot in those days—I am just wondering whether the minister might address himself to those particular questions that I have asked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Deputy Chairman, I will address some remarks to those points. The effect of what the Labor Party is proposing quite clearly would restrict the Productivity Commission's functions to inquiries. We think that is overly restrictive. We do not think it is in Australia's interests to set up a commission which, if the Labor Party had its way, would not even be able to do what the Industry Commission under Labor was able to do. In fact—and I would have to check on this—even EPAC and BIE would have had broader powers than these.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine used the florid language of `letting a tiger loose' in relation to the commission being able to undertake, of its own initiative, research on other matters. Senator Harradine, you said that this is like setting a tiger free. Having a tiger running around the country perhaps is not in the public interest, certainly from a public safety point of view. But we think that allowing a commission that has these objectives, of its own initiative, to undertake matters that look at industry and productivity is a worthwhile thing.

Clearly, the Industry Commission can do this at the moment. I think, from memory, EPAC used to be able to do that too. Certainly, to ensure basically that the Productivity Commission has to go to the Treasurer or send him a brief to say, `We propose to do some research on this industry' or `that industry' or `that productivity issue,' and for the Treasurer to have to decide whether or not the commission should undertake that project, is extremely inefficient; quite frankly, it is a waste of the scarce time of the Treasurer. As I have been reminded, the commission can only make recommendations, anyway.

Senator Harradine, to use your analogy of the tiger being cut loose and the gates being opened on its cage, in my view Labor's amendments would not only put the tiger in a very tight cage but also shoot it with a tranquilliser dart. I do not think you would want a Productivity Commission that is so restricted in its functions that it would lie with glazed eyes on the bottom of a cage waiting for advice from the Treasurer about when it might get up and do something.

The coalition believes that the functions set out in part 2 of the bill are sensible. They reflect the coalition's policy announcement that we would incorporate the existing functions of the Industry Commission, the BIE and EPAC into a Productivity Commission. What we have done here is to enumerate those functions.

Senator Harradine, in your comments you talked about productivity councils and the like. I think it is quite appropriate that the commission have the functions which are described in part (f) in relation to promoting understanding of these issues. But, furthermore, one would hope that productivity issues are promoted by a whole range of other organisations, including trade unions—which I know they could do and have done in the past.

Productivity should be seen as something that is not a dirty word. It should be something that is seen as a way of helping to generate economic growth, economic development and employment. It should not be seen as a way of slashing jobs or whatever. It is a bit like entrepreneurship. We got a pretty nasty name in the 1980s, but entrepreneurship is a very good thing for an economy, as is productivity.

I think for a Senate particularly to take away this function from a commission not only would constrain the commission when it got set up but also would send a terrible message to the Australian people saying, `We don't want the commission to promote this; we don't want it to be able to undertake research in these matters.' I really do wonder at the motives of those moving this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I think Senator Campbell—and I will be charitable—has inadvertently misled the Senate by saying that the powers we propose for the Productivity Commission are even less than those that existed under the old Industry Commission. I have a copy of the old Industry Commission Act here and, in fact, looking at it, what we are inserting I think is identical to what is contained therein.

SPEECH.PARA: The great problem or concern we have, Senator Harradine—and I have reiterated this over and over again—is that we believed in a split, competitive model: three different organisations, with three different functions, responsibilities, reporting to different ministers. If we are taking this analogy that the Productivity Commission or the Industry Commission is the tiger, in respect of the Productivity Commission the tiger exists as before. The tiger is on a leash. It is let loose occasionally. It slashes and burns. We do not like some of the results. But you can pull it back into line by ensuring that its functions and guidelines are controllable.

If we make the analogy that EPAC is the elephant and BIE is the lion, and you combine all three together, we have a horrendous beast indeed. It has no leash at all, particularly when it is under the direction of the Treasurer. Also, effectively, considering the accountability we had previously with the other three organisations, with BIE reporting to the industry minister, and EPAC to the Prime Minister, I am sure that the industry minister, Mr Moore—although I have never seen any statement from him—would be less than happy at what has happened to the BIE.

If this government wants to narrow the various diverse and, in many cases, very important independent reports which were brought down under the three previous organisations, and if it wants to combine those organisations, we will not be happy with that. If, at the end of the day, we are to support this legislation, we want to ensure that the tiger is as controlled as before. I think Senator Harradine would understand that, if you combine three different organisations, with all of their previous powers and responsibilities, the effective outcome is much greater. The authority that it has is much greater than the power and authority which the three individual organisations had previously. That really is the essence of Labor's concerns with the government's approach to the Productivity Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some points that Senator Sherry raised. The government fundamentally disagrees with the concept that we are narrowing the advice. Any assessment of the amount of economic advice that is available now compared with the early 1980s, when I watched EPAC being formed, for example, totally avoids the fact that there has been a significant increase in the number and quality of independent economic advisory organisations and other forms of economic advice to government. That is a fact. I flippantly said—but on a half‐serious note—that most of the people who go to these organisations have either come from EPAC, or BIE, or Treasury or other spheres of government or quasi‐government organisations, because economic advice has become a most contestable marketplace now.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I would seek to make is that the power and authority of a body like the Productivity Commission, or any other organisation in terms of economic advice, will not be created because of its functions or anything else that can be made by the creator of the organisation. It will come down to the quality of its work, the quality of its contribution to the public debate and the effectiveness of its advice. We cannot create an organisation out of this place and give it power and authority. It can only do so in this area by building its own credibility.

Senator Sherry referred to the powers under the existing Industry Commission Act. The point I made—and I did not seek to mislead the Senate; I sought to inform the Senate—was that the Industry Commission undertakes the functions that are described in the functions of the commission section already. The Industry Commission has used a very wide definition of the incidental power in doing its work. The bill seeks to reflect the reality as it stands at the moment.

The other point I would make, if Senator Sherry is to be taken seriously in relation to wanting EPAC to be regarded as an independent, vigorous, strong and powerful voice of economic advice, is that EPAC's role and function ran down under Labor, particularly over the last couple of years. Senator Sherry would have read that article in the Business Review Weekly towards the dying days of the Keating government, where people from EPAC and former people from EPAC said that their role had been virtually gutted in the last couple of years.

Another point is that the BIE never had any sort of statutory base. I want to reinforce the fact that there is plenty of advice out there these days, probably more under this government than there was in the final years of the Keating government. Every time the Keating government needed to get a policy invigoration, it used to have a panic meeting and say, `Let's have a One Nation' or `Let's have a Working Nation'. It would create an enormous flurry of midnight activity to come up with the next policy document, finding ways to spend billions of dollars to churn people through unemployment streams.

In the short time that the coalition has been in government, we have sought advice from quite serious independent inquiries, such as the Wallis financial systems inquiry, to which the government has responded today, the Mortimer inquiry and Professor Goldsworthy's inquiry into information technology. The whole scene of economic advice and industry advice to government has changed significantly since the early 1980s.

We are seeking to reform the current regime by bringing together advice into an efficient and effective modern economic advisory commission for this government in the guise of the Productivity Commission. We think saving $22.5 million in the process is an appropriate way to do it. We do not want to see that commission restricted by limiting its functions in the way that the opposition have proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two brief comments. I want to reiterate my concern that, if you combine the powers of three previous organisations—even if we accept Senator Campbell's point that EPAC was run down—you will ultimately have a body with much greater power than the individual powers of the three previous bodies that it is replacing.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not yet commented on the new subsection 1 and subsection 2 to which we have added `matters relating to industry development and productivity'. This should be seen in the context of our next amendment in respect of policy guidelines for the commission. With this organisation we are seeking to put a much stronger emphasis for the Productivity Commission on industry development—not simply productivity but industry development and productivity.

There is a range of additional policy guidelines that we will get to shortly with respect to issues such as growth in employment in regional areas, and promotion of regional development. We believe that in such a new organisation, and given the current significant economic restructuring that is occurring, particularly in rural and regional areas—and particularly in my home state of Tasmania—the Productivity Commission should have a much more significant emphasis on industry development and productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be very long. Last night I did mention to the committee that it is important to have independent advice on economic matters, productivity matters, et cetera, from a source not under the control of the Treasury. The Treasury is a great department of the Public Service—perhaps a key, if not the key, department—and I respect the huge number of officers in that department who have the relevant expertise and are beavering away on matters of great importance to this nation. Mind you, I have got a question for tomorrow which perhaps throws some of that in doubt, but we will wait until then.

BREAK.PARA: I agree with what has been said around the chamber that there is a need for a diversity of views and advice to government on these particular matters. I indicated last night that although the Industry Commission reports to the Treasurer, it does take views which are quite different from Treasury's views. I think I mentioned on that occasion the question of cost recovery for regulatory agencies. I have a copy of a report entitled Regulation and its Review, 1994‐95, which was undertaken by the commission. It goes quite effectively and deeply into the matter and it comes down with advice which appears to me, on the face of it, to be somewhat different from some of the advice that ministers have received from Treasury.

At some stages, of course, Treasury's advice to ministers would be the advice that the ministers accept and, on other occasions, other advice. But what does worry me overall is the problem we might get into in that, with the abolition of EPAC and BIE and the ability they had of giving separate advice to ministers—and to different ministers at that—we are not going to have that now. Obviously the Labor Party amendments are not going to retain either EPAC or BIE. What concerns me is that unless we have the commission performing the functions that EPAC and BIE were able to perform, we are going to open the way for the suggestion that Treasury has the field on its own.

Quite obviously other departments will have their say about industry policy and productivity policy; there is no doubt about that. As has been said by other senators, various groups—industry groups, the trade union movement and others—will obviously have their say. But I feel that if 6(1)(b) does not come within the scope of the Labor Party's amendment—if, for example, the commission is unable to provide secretariat services and research services to government bodies as directed by the minister—then it ought to be there, because these services are currently undertaken. I have had another look at 6(1)(e) as I have been listening to the debate. It says:
to undertake, on its own initiative, research about matters relating to industry and productivity;
I suppose, as Senator Campbell has indicated, that is not letting the tiger out to roam at will. They can undertake the research—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a sniffer dog.
—No, it is actually doing research. I assume that that research will be available to members of parliament and industry on request—or FOI matters—or whatever. It also says:

BREAK.PARA: (f) to promote public understanding of matters relating to industry and productivity.

Under the circumstances, I am inclined now to vote against amendment 6(1), but for opposition amendment 6(2). The point that Senator Sherry makes is a very valid one. I would like to ask that the question, if need be, be put in that manner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Campbell). Senator Harradine has indicated his position in respect of the functions. Could I ask: did EPAC or the Bureau of Industry Economics have the same powers in respect of part 7, which relates to offences? I assume they did not, but I would just like confirmation that neither EPAC nor BIE had what we consider to be very extensive powers. I know the old Industry Commission did, but as I understand it we are conferring the same powers of the old Industry Commission on a new body which has much greater scope and functional responsibility.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The BIE could not have had them because it was not a statutory body. I do not have advice on EPAC, but I would doubt it. I can see how it relates to functions; I can see how you could draw a bow. I think it would be appropriate to speak about powers. But as I understand it we are conferring the same powers on this body that the Industry Commission had. EPAC had only 10 people in March 1996 and probably would not have had the people to implement the power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out to Senator Harradine that this highlights our concern. We are effectively conferring the old functions of BIE and EPAC—or most of them—onto a new body, in combination with the Industry Commission which is going into the Productivity Commission. In the course of doing that, Senator Harradine, the old Industry Commission, by incorporating the functions of the previous two organisations other than the Industry Commission, will be able to exercise its method of operation powers under part 7, for example, in a greatly enhanced form because of greatly enhanced functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst some offences would be considered reasonable in respect of the operation of the Industry Commission, would they have been considered reasonable in respect of the operation of EPAC or the BIE, whose functions we are largely transferring to the Productivity Commission? With a greatly enhanced functional responsibility in addition to the old Industry Commission, they will be able to exercise powers in respect of hindering or disrupting the commission; intimidation; notice to persons to provide information and documents; summons to persons to attend hearings; refusal to answer questions or produce documents; preservation of the privilege against self‐incrimination; and false or misleading evidence or information.

That is why I asked the question of Senator Campbell. I do not believe that organisations such as the BIE and EPAC, that are being replaced, effectively having their functions transferred to the new Productivity Commission, should be able to exercise the sort of powers outlined in part 7. As I said earlier, it is a combination of three different organisations with vastly different functions and also with vastly different powers in respect of offences. As I said, a number of these offences may be appropriate in respect of the old Industry Commission, but I certainly do not think they are reasonable in the context of the functions that we appear to be giving approval to here.

I do not want to take the time of the committee unnecessarily. Could I just ask for some guidance about splitting the functions of the commission in the two parts of the amendment and, in effect, splitting the amendment before the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the committee to deal with it that way.
—Senator Sherry is saying that he has amendments on part 7, and we will no doubt come to that debate then. I am supporting part 2 of the amendment but not part 1.
—The question is that proposed subclause 6(1) be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that subclause 6(2), moved by Senator Sherry, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Campbell was going to propose a different wording which would accommodate us in respect to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the Democrats are supporting this amendment, are they, Senator Murray?
—Yes, we will support this amendment.

—As I said, I have noticed the numbers in this place. What I am suggesting, instead of losing the whole thing, is to try to salvage something. The government would be happy to accept the amendment if we were to insert in subsection (1) where it says `matters relating to industry development and productivity' the word `industry,' so it would now read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity includes . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you just repeat that, please?

—In the proposed new section 6(2), instead of Senator Sherry's proposed words, which would read `matters relating to industry development and productivity', the words would now read `industry, industry development and productivity'. We would have thought industry was an inclusive sort of word which would have included industry development, but we think these words would be even more inclusive. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "matters relating to industry development", substitute "matters relating to industry, industry development".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will accept that. I have to say, it does not make one hell of a difference, frankly. Given the failure of the Senate to pass our amendments to the functions, I suppose what is important, in addition to the points we have dealt with, will be the next amendment, which outlines the performance of the commission's functions. I suppose we will read our success in respect to this in the context of how amendment No. 3 goes. But we can certainly live with the proposed change.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Campbell's) agreed to.
Clause 6(2), as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 6, page 5 (line 8), at the end of subclause (2), add:

PARA.TAB: ;and (b) the desirability of industries developing in a way which is ecologically sustainable; and
(c) the necessity for the benefits of productivity performance of industry to flow through to the Australian people in terms of increased employment and improved living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to, if I may, attack section 6(2) from a different direction. Section 6(2) says in (a), (b) and (c):
. . . matters relating to industry and productivity includes:

PARA.TAB: (a) the productivity performance of industry or of the economy as a whole; and
(b) any factor that affects or might affect productivity performance, including labour market practices; and
(c) legislative or administrative action taken, or to be taken, by the Commonwealth . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We think that is too constraining and we have added (d) and (e) which have the following words:

PARA.TAB: (d) the desirability of industries developing in a way which is ecologically sustainable; and
(e) the necessity for the benefits of productivity performance of industry to flow through to the Australian people in terms of increased employment and improved living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Campbell was making the point earlier that he wants an expansive rather than a contracted role for the commission. Now we are giving you the opportunity to take a holistic view and to encourage the commission to take a holistic and inclusive view of society as a whole.

Our amendment seeks to broaden the definition of matters relating to industry and productivity to include the very important conditions relating to the environment—and we regard the environment in the widest sense—and who the ultimate beneficiaries are. Our proposed paragraph (d) seeks to ensure that it be recognised that the principles for ecologically sustainable development are essential to productivity, especially in the long term.

We cannot maintain industries which are environmentally unsustainable because eventually productivity will fall. Similarly, we have to ask who the beneficiaries of industrial development are. We believe that benefits should be measured in terms of higher living standards and increased employment.

One of our problems with the language of the bill is that it is very utilitarian, very dehumanising. Ultimately, we seek—all of us in this chamber from our different directions—to increase the living standards of Australians and to provide them with a happier and more inclusive society.

Frankly, we think without that sort of approach the changes you are proposing are not worth doing because we think economics should serve society and not vice versa. We have attempted, therefore, to give that flavour to your approach. I therefore commend our amendment No. 1 to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendment. We do not disagree with the concept of ecologically sustainable development, but we think those sorts of concepts and living standards—matters that Senator Murray raised; matters that are important to the coalition—should not need to be put into this section of the bill. They are matters that are quite properly, appropriately and very importantly handled in guidelines. I think we should look at those issues when we get to that stage of the debate on the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will be supporting these amendments. I think Senator Murray outlined very adequately the reasons for this. From my previous responsibilities as parliamentary secretary in the primary industries portfolio, I know that if, for example, water reform issues were to be addressed by the Productivity Commission, given what I fear are the enormous problems we face in that industry, we would have to take into account the ecological sustainability of those reforms, and the same applies to anything that may be considered by the Productivity Commission. Part (e) of the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: the necessity for the benefits of productivity performance of industry to flow through to the Australian people in terms of increased employment and improved living standards.

Senator Campbell talked about the necessity for trade unions to talk about the benefits of productivity. I think if the wider community is to understand and accept the benefits of productivity, and certainly Labor does, we should try to overcome some of the fear in the community about words like `productivity' and `efficiency'.

Frankly, Senator Campbell, when I talk to people at a corner pub about productivity and efficiency, you would have thought I had poisoned their drink, as their eyes glaze over when I talk about these sorts of terms. I never start a speech by lauding productivity and efficiency when I am out talking to what I consider are Labor's constituency. It is a good way to end your life. And I am pretty sure you would get the same reaction from small business, farmers and the like.

It is jargon that is not commonly understood or appreciated, and I think that is unfortunate. I think that, if we and the Productivity Commission can at least reshape some of the debate by placing an appropriate emphasis on increasing employment and improved living standards that result from productivity, it will be a very substantial step forward in the debate that is occurring at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —If the government had its way, we might run out of places to look when we deal with the issue of ecological sustainability. If it is not possible for entities like the Productivity Commission to have heed to things like ecological sustainability, what is it we are saying they are there for?

SPEECH.PARA: Ecological sustainability is not just about the environment. It is about being able to continue earning a living in the future—not just destroying what we have now. You would think that, along with the competitive pressures, those issues ought to be considered and that there are balances—and the balances are what you are going to get out of it. There is not much point in increasing productivity for the sake of it. This is what I think the Senate is saying at the moment: productivity should be reaching a certain end, and that is the improvement of things. If you have a book entry which appears to improve productivity but it has actually destroyed your natural capital, you have not actually gained anything.

I guess we are suggesting that the measures should be a step in the right direction rather than destroying either employment prospects or the ability for people to be able to enjoy their living and make a living in the future. That is what it is all about. As I say, you cannot keep putting it somewhere else, because there is nowhere else to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the premise of Senator Margetts which is that on the face of it—she should read page 5 of the bill—we are trying to find places to hide this. Senator Margetts, please read subclause 8(e) of the bill, which says `to recognise the social and environmental consequences of measures proposed by the Commission'. Please listen when I say we think that referring to ecologically sustainable development in the functions of the commission is not the right place to do so, but it is in the guidelines. It is a matter of how you run it effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not hiding from the importance of environmental considerations. Senator Sherry made a very good point. Senator Sherry referred to issues relating to water rights I think in the context of when he was a parliamentary secretary. In relation to forestry, if we had looked at bringing some sensible economics into the ownership of forests and the allocation of resources within forests 30 years ago, we would not have the plundering of forests that we have at the moment. Forests have effectively been controlled by state‐owned monopolies for most of the history of Australia, and state‐owned monopolies do not allocate resources efficiently and they create ecological damage in the process.

We know that the return for the wood coming out of Giblett Block is probably not what is driving that process at the moment. Good economics can be good for the environment as well, and in many parts of Australia that does not occur. We do not hide from that. We know that efficiency and good economics can deliver good outcomes, and we have recognised it in—and Senator Margetts has not read them or refuses to—the general policy guidelines to the commission. They are mentioned quite explicitly on the very same page of the bill. We are not hiding it. We have put it in there in black and white, right up front.

Senator Murray, in respect of your proposed addition of subclauses (d) and (e), what we are saying is that they will have to be re‐numbered because the last amendment we passed has wiped out 2(a), (b) and (c). You are proposing to add (d) and (e) so you will, if you want to make this correct, have to re‐letter those particular additions in relation to `ecologically sustainable' industry and also in relation to `the necessity for the benefits of productivity performance of industry to flow through to the Australian people in terms of increased employment and improved living standards'.

Senator Murray, you know very well that is exactly what the government is on about. I have said that three or four times in this debate. Having productivity for productivity's sake is just stupid. You do not pursue these sorts of economic terms for some sort of gratification. You do it to improve living standards and to improve employment, and there is a big political incentive to do that, as you know as well.

I am suggesting to the chamber that the government would quite happily, to add emphasis to 8(1)(e)—`under general policy guidelines', add the two sections that Senator Murray proposes. We are quite happy to do that and I would foreshadow—with an indication of support—that I would be prepared to move in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I seek your advice on the question of numbering. I say to Senator Campbell, through the chair: You have just established that certainly your intention and your heart is in the right place. In other words, you support ecological sustainability; you support taking into account full social and environmental consequences; you support maximising living standards and you support advancing employment. My intention is that, if I lose this amendment, I will take you up on this and I will propose that those words then go further down. But it is our opinion that it is the function of the commission, not a general policy guideline, to ensure that industries develop in a way that is ecologically sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like you to tell me why you do not think it is the function of industries to develop in a way that is ecologically sustainable. As to the other section that we have got there, we believe it is the function of the commission to make sure that the benefits of productivity performance of industry flow through to the Australian people in terms of increased employment and improved living standards. What other function can there be? I do not understand your rejection, given your commitment to the broad philosophy and policy directions which we have laid out with our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect we did that for the same reasons that you rejected referring to labour market practices and the other matters that were in (a), (b) and (c) and which you have just voted out. What I have said is consistent. What we are saying is that 6(2) says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity include . . . the following is part of the functions . . .
You chose for your good reasons to knock out:
. . . any factor that affects or might affect productivity performance including labour market practices . . .
You probably had a very good reason for knocking that out—
or productivity performance of industry or the economy as a whole.

We are saying that (2), as it is amended, stands as a broad picture of the functions of the commission. I have pointed out that 8(e) already refers to `social and environmental consequences' and, most importantly, I have foreshadowed that we think that is the right place for that consideration to go. It says:
In the performance of its functions, the commission must have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth government . . .
to do these things. Under your amendments, which I have just indicated we would support, the commission would have to:
have regard to the desire of the Commonwealth government to:
(i) ensure industry develops in a way that is ecologically sustainable . . .
We have given that the tick. We have agreed with you there. We have agreed the commission should have regard to that. We have also said that the commission should have regard to identifying:
. . . the likely employment and social effects of any measures proposed by the Commission and means of ameliorating any adverse employment and social effects.

We have agreed to support your amendment. In fact, your proposed wording in subclause 6(e) is slightly different from that in (g). I have just picked that up. I have already told you I am happy to pick up (e) as well. We just think that is the appropriate place to put it. We are saying that the com mission must have regard to these things—it is a very specific direction. It is not a function, but in performing its functions it much have regard to these things and we think that strikes the right balance and I hope that, by the government quite happily agreeing to include these extra policy guidelines, which the commission must have regard to, that will be a strong statement and it will be a strong statement from the Senate to say that they reflect the desire of the Commonwealth government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, we need to resolve the numbering. The subclauses will become subclauses (b) and (c), rather than (d) and (e), to suit the circumstances.
—I accept that, if the Senate is happy with it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a comment while we are on the subject of numbering. Senator Murray, I would suggest that if you are happy to accept my logic—which I do not assume at this stage because I am just putting a proposal to you—you could withdraw your amendment No. 1. As for your amendment No. 2, which is to clause 8, that would include a new subclause (f), which relates to ecological sustainability, and a new subclause (g), which talks about ameliorating any adverse employment and social effects. Your subclause (e) in your amendment No. 1 would become (h) in amendment No. 2. So you would have (f) relating to ecological sustainability, (g) relating to adverse employment and social effects, et cetera, and (e) relating to the benefits of productivity performance all forming part of the new general policy guidelines.

—Parliamentary Secretary, I thank you for your answer and I thank you for your cooperativeness. I think we will agree to disagree for the moment, but I will take you up on your offer when we move on to clause 8. For the purposes of the amendment—and I do not intend to hold the Senate up any further—can we renumber No. 1 on sheet 612 so that (d) and (e) become (b) and (c) respectively?
—The original amendment will become (a), so you do not really need to do anything. I am advised that it will be automatic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —What the minister has indicated to Senator Murray is reasonable. I hope there will be a further change to numbering because 8(c) is a matter about which I have some considerable concern. We have yet to debate Senator Sherry's amendments to clause 8, which may indeed be preferred by the committee to the clause 8 that is currently in the bill. For the moment let us focus on the amendment before us. My inclination is to vote against that amendment and deal with it in clause 8.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 8, page 5 (line 13) to page 6 (line 3), omit the clause, substitute:
(1) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must give priority to:

PARA.TAB: (a) encouraging the development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive; and
(b) facilitating adjustment to structural changes in the economy and avoidance of social and economic hardships arising from those changes; and
(c) recognition of the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community, likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission; and
(d) growth in employment, including in regional areas; and
(e) promotion of regional development; and
(f) Australia's international obligations; and
(g) progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non‐tariff barriers.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In the performance of its functions, the Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified to it in writing by the Minister.
(3) Where a matter is referred to the Commission for inquiry and report, the Commission must:

PARA.TAB: (a) report on the basis of methodologies, assessments and recommendations adopted by the Commission; and

(b) inquire into and report on social, economic and environmental consequences of any recommendations it makes, including the consequences for the distribution of employment, income, resources and services between individuals and groups in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important amendment for the Labor opposition. As I have referred to in this debate on a number of occasions so far, we are combining the functions of three organisations into one. We have particular concerns about the flow‐on consequences of that; and we have dealt with the issue of contestable advice, so I will not go over that again.

In dealing with the general policy guidelines for the new Productivity Commission we believe that there should be, to some extent, a refocus of the old Industry Commission policy guidelines, particularly given this combination of the functions of the three previous organisations which, regrettably, the committee has agreed to.

The other very important reason is the new and emerging trend in the economy because of which, rather than seeing a slowdown in the pace of economic change, we are seeing it accelerate. Rather than people being relaxed and comfortable, as the Prime Minister said at the last election that he wished them to be—a bit like the little fairy coming down and waving the wand over the Australian electorate and saying, `Be relaxed and comfortable and the world will change tomorrow when a Liberal government is elected'—if anything, the uncertainty and the fear of change has gotten worse in the last year. In part that has been because of what has occurred as a consequence of the two budgets. That is another issue, but I think it is relevant.

We are seeking to rewrite clause 8, which involves the general policy guidelines to be followed by the commission. We believe that this is one of the great weaknesses of the current bill that the government is proposing. The government has completely neglected some very significant policy guidelines in the context of this combination of three organisations and in the context of the continuing accelerating change in the economy. We propose to insert what we believe are neglected policy guidelines. This policy neglect has been a consistent theme of the government since its election.

We believe the commission must give priority to encouraging the development and growth of Australian industry and to the avoidance of social and economic hardships arising from structural adjustment. We must recognise the interests of industries, employees and consumers. Also, the promotion of regional development is very important in the context of the economic change that is occurring. Of course, there was a time when probably the last socialist party in Australia, the National Party, were protecting the interests of regional development in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The national socialist party.

—I take the interjection. I am not sure I would agree with you totally, although I do note that no members of the National Party have participated in this debate, as in most economic debates. But, then, I think they have given up the ghost for regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that there is an emphasis on the promotion of regional development and, again, the progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers. I acknowledge that there is significant scepticism in the Australian community about the benefits of reduction in tariffs if Australia were to progress the reform of Australian industry by having a further reduction in tariffs. Continually we are confronted with arguments about what is occurring with our trading partners, particularly in the east Asian and north Asian regions.

Labor certainly does not believe in a process of continual reductions of tariffs down to zero. Labor is not a zero tariff party. It never has been and never will be. The place for tariffs is as part of an industry policy mix to allow industries to develop and grow. We have made reference to the recent Industry Commission interim report on textiles, cloth ing and footwear. In that context, what is just as important as the tariff barrier is the positive assistance offered to industry by, for example, the import credit scheme in the TCF area.

They are assistance programs on which the Industry Commission is absolutely unwavering in its advocacy of cutting, slashing and burning. I would regard myself as a relative economic rationalist, but even I was shocked by the evidence of Mr Kerr, the head of the Industry Commission, at a recent estimates committee. I do not want to be unduly harsh on him—in fact, he would probably be proud of the fact that I am referring to him in this debate—but I have never seen a person so zealous in advocating getting rid of all industry assistance and all tariffs—getting rid of it all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You appointed him.
—As I say, Senator Campbell, I was shocked at the zealous advocacy of Mr Kerr. To be fair to him, in the area of R&D there was some credit.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Nick, show some good humour and acknowledge that one.

—Obviously we have to have regard to our international obligations. I heard the National Party comment; I did hear your comment, Senator O'Chee. I was not going to acknowledge the interjection. I learned in my early days to acknowledge the interjections only when you want them on the record. I note that you, Senator O'Chee, did not respond when I referred to your party as being the last socialist party in Australia and rapidly dying.
—I just thought the comment was so silly it didn't need acknowledging.

—I will take that interjection. Socialism for the National Party is great so long as it begins 100 kilometres outside of the CBDs of Australia's major urban areas. I think that that is the basis of their ideology. But that is a debate for another time.
—Unless it is in the head office of the marketing board.

—I will take that interjection, Senator Campbell. You are dead right: if the head office of the marketing board is in the CBD, the Nationals are very keen on it. I notice there is a number of National Party senators who have their head offices in the CBD of Melbourne these days, too. Senator McGauran is a real Collins Street farmer in more ways than one.
—This is very unproductive.
—And very unfair.
—It is very unfair. Although, Senator McGauran did attempt to defend himself in a previous debate. But time is rushing on.
—You are wandering, Senator Sherry.

—It is a legitimate wander. My whip is giving me the flag. This is a very important amendment for Labor in ensuring that the material factors that are facing Australia here and now, and which Australia is likely to face in the coming decades, are taken into account by the commission when undertaking their analysis. These must be central to any advice provided, not merely an afterthought.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a further attempt to ensure that the advice from the commission is practical in its outlook and not overly theoretically based. I have made some comments about the National Party. Frankly, if National Party senators do not support this amendment, they are voting against their own interests and against regional development, and especially against regional employment.

I conclude by making a brief reference to my own home state of Tasmania and the region of Tasmania. It is in crisis. We are facing an economic, employment, job security and industrial development crisis. I wish I knew all the answers. It is a crisis that is occurring in many other areas of rural and regional Australia. If the Productivity Commission is to continue operating with the enhanced functions of EPAC, BIE and the old Industry Commission, the policy guidelines under which it is to operate need to be refocused.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at the government proposal in the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 , and if you look at the amendments proposed by the opposition and the Australian Democrats, you will see that we are all generally heading in the same direction. While Senator Sherry has been speaking about a whole range of matters—even including what is in the bill—I have been working to try to seek a compromise proposal, and senators may try to catch it as I read it. The government would propose to support a restructuring of the general policy guidelines for the commission along these lines—I have provided the opposition's advisers box with the proposal, but I have not been able to get up to Senator Murray's end of the chamber at this stage.
—Nor this end of the chamber.
—Or even Senator Harradine's end.
—And Senator Harradine is pretty important.

—Very important. We propose to keep in the bill clause 8(1)(a), which says `to improve the overall economic performance of the economy through higher productivity' et cetera. We would concede (b). We would keep (c), which, for the sake of the clerks or whoever is trying to keep track of this, would become a new (b) to read `to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States' and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: We would agree to Labor's (a), (b) and (c), which, for the sake of this exercise, would become (c), (d) and (e). We think we can achieve a combination of Labor's (d), (e) and (g) in a more concise form. The words that we suggest in a new (f) are `promote employment growth, including in regional areas and regional development, and take account of the trade policies of other countries'. So that brings together Labor's (d), (e) and (g), which were focusing on regional employment, regional development, international obligations and trade policy, including tariff and non-tariff barriers. Then (g) and (h) would be the Democrat amendments, currently Demo crat amendment No. 2 in this case, which would bring in that (f) and (g), which is delivering on the promise I made a few minutes ago in relation to that. I think that would be a fairly comprehensive set of guidelines which the coalition would be happy to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for making a very solid attempt at compromise. But, given the expansion of the functions of the Productivity Commission, and that debate has gone and we have lost on that, we are certainly not happy with clause 8(1)(c) continuing—that is, `to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth government'. The reason we are not happy is the continued inclusion of this.

SPEECH.PARA: There are vastly enhanced functions for the Productivity Commission. We would be concerned that the Productivity Commission—and it would have the power to do this, I think, given what has occurred in the Senate to date—could roam wherever whenever and do whatever in the context of the enhanced functions in respect of states, territories and local government. We think that is undesirable and that is why we wanted to drop (c).

We do have a competition policy process whether we like it or not. I am sure the competition policy was introduced after the Industry Commission came into being. We think that, if there is going to be policy coordination involvement with respect to the reduction of regulation of industry, there is an agreed mechanism. That is the competition policy mechanism. That has been signed off by the states. We do not think there should be another enhanced body with the sorts of functions, powers and responsibilities that this body has so far—and I hope does not have when we get to sections later on—delving into the areas of the states, territories and local government. We just do not think that is appropriate.

Senator CAMPBELL (Western Australia—Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer) (6.27 p.m.)—I will make one observation and I will be brief. I am not sure, Senator Sherry, whether you are indicating that the rest of the proposal is okay. We probably will get to a vote on this. This is not to say that this makes it holy writ, but (c) is a direct transcription of the identical clause in the general policy guidelines to the Industry Commission legislation that the previous government enacted through this place in 1990. It is an exact transcription and an exact power that the Industry Commission has under its current general policy guidelines.

Senator Sherry is quite right: the competition process has improved discussions on competition productivity and competitive neutrality issues between the states and the Commonwealth. I give credit where it is due to the previous Prime Minister in moving that policy along. I think it was a very good initiative of the previous government and a great credit to the previous Prime Minister. But I do think that staying vigilant on these matters and the Productivity Commission having this within its general policy guidelines remain important.

I do not think anybody who takes an interest in these matters would think that the problem has been solved. There is a long way to go in this area. The Commonwealth can do a lot in terms of reducing red tape and unnecessary regulation, which does not have a benefit, which does not stand up to any cost‐benefit analysis. The Commonwealth government can go a long way, but there is an enormous amount of work that needs to be done across the nation in other jurisdictions at different levels of government. To remove the provision that the previous government put into the Industry Commission legislation in 1990 would be giving some sort of indication—the Labor Party seems to be giving this indication now—that seven years down the track the work is over. The work has just begun. It was to Mr Keating and his government's credit that they commenced that competition policy work, bringing the states into this regime. But the work is not over. There is an enormous amount of work that needs to be done.

BREAK.PARA: The Productivity Commission can make a contribution in this area and should make a contribution. I would need to be better convinced by the Labor Party that all of a sudden, seven years after putting this sensible clause into the 1990 legislation, the Productivity Commission would not need to continue its work in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I emphasise that the National Competition Council process is one that has been agreed to between the states and the Commonwealth. From what I have seen, it is doing a relatively good job. I would not endorse everything it has done, but I have had some briefings from it and, as agreed to by the states, there is a process in place, with appropriate payments of moneys. I think we have just agreed to that in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Why then continue with what is obviously an overlapping responsibility in (c)—and a responsibility I do not think the states, territories and local governments would be very happy with, particularly given the enhanced functions of the Productivity Commission? Subclause (c) says:
. . . where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government

In the hands of an enhanced Productivity Commission, as I read it, this power means that, if there is any area of regulation of industry in a state, territory or local government that is inconsistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth, as announced, the Commonwealth can say to the Productivity Commission, `Go in and have a look at this. It is inconsistent. Go in and thoroughly examine it'—with all the powers that are attached.

Part 7 of the bill—`Offences etc.'—would be very effective in coercing states, territories and local governments into line. I would hope that there would be some restriction on the manner in which these powers could be exercised. But, putting aside the powers issue, we do not believe, in the context of the National Competition Council—which seems to be operating effectively—and in the context of the enhanced functions, that it is appropriate for (c) to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the government's proposal to merge references to Australia's international obligations and to progress made by Australia's trading partners in reducing both tariff and non‐tariff barriers into something about trade policies of other countries. There is almost no connection between the two. Australia's international obligations are manyfold and they are about, in your guidelines, looking at the other things Australia has to keep in mind at the same time. Trade policies are automatically imposed on Australia, unfortunately, in every element of what we—state, federal and local governments—do.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Competition Council was mentioned. The National Competition Council is currently reviewing around 2,000 pieces of legislation Australia‐wide to see whether they are anti‐competitive. Those changes are being rolled over at a very fast rate, but to suggest that you can swap giving priority to Australia's international obligations and to progress made by Australia's trading partners with giving priority to trade policies of other countries is ludicrous. I certainly would not suggest a swap of those terms in anything suggested by the government. What has been suggested as a substitution is not in any way equivalent to what we had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to look at a rewording of it. It was a suggestion to try to get three or four things into one. The government is not in the business of ignoring international obligations—particularly trade agreement obligations—and we are happy to reword that. Perhaps a sensible suggestion is that getting a consensus over this might be better outside the chamber. I would propose that we adjourn consideration of clause 8—`General policy guidelines for commission'—and move on to the next item. We have only about 20 minutes of government business time left, unless we want to try to negate going on to the next item of business.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry spoke about the commission having these powers. While I am on my feet, I would like to repeat—to get it on the record—that it is in the Industry Commission bill. Peter Morris, when he was speaking to the bill back in 1989, said it was important that the Industry Commission had this power. This power is no greater than the power the Industry Commission has, and the Labor Party seemed to think that was a good idea in 1990.
In the House of Representatives on 2 November 1989, Peter Morris said that the commission was:
. . . a source of analysis and information on matters relating to the Australian economy in general—not just those matters falling within the purview of the Commonwealth Government.

Senator Sherry seems to be saying that the commission is a boosted commission which has got enormous powers. He said that we are combining EPAC and the BIE. I was only advised later that EPAC was down to 10 people by the time these guys left power! They so cared about EPAC as a competitive source of advice and about this concept of contestability of advice that they ran EPAC down to 10 people. I do not know whether that included administrative support.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't like the fact that EPAC was reporting that people said they wanted to spend more money on the environment.
—We have read that report, Senator Margetts, and we are spending $1 billion more. So we accepted that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument about the increased powers of this new mega‐commission is just totally spurious. Firstly, there are no more powers. Secondly, the powers only relate to public inquiries; they are restricted—and, Senator Sherry, I think you know that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very substantial power.

—It is. It is a power that was put in there and agreed to by the previous government. It is interesting to note that there has been such a significant change. I cannot condemn you for being hypocritical on this matter, because you and I were not here in November 1989 or early 1990. We arrived not long after that time. You probably would have crossed the floor on this one.

BREAK.PARA: Having responded to that point, I would propose that we could make progress on this outside of the chamber. We are quite serious about trying to find a consensus on the guidelines, and I do not think that consensus is too far away.

Senator Margetts, I indicate that we are prepared to look at international obligations and other matters as part of trying to find a rewording of those three proposals by the Labor Party. So we are prepared to include that idea. Mine was just an on the rush, back of the envelope, first blush suggestion for trying to define that. But it would be better if it were to continue. Therefore, I move:
That further consideration of the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I then presume that, in the spirit of that motion by Senator Campbell, the Democrats will not be moving their amendments to clause 8, and we move now to Senator Sherry's clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1— Clause 10, page 6 (line 17 to 20), omit subclause (2), substitue:

PARA.TAB: (2) In the report, the Commission must report on matters relating to industry development and productivity that have been referred to it.

This pair of amendments reflects Labor's preferred focus for the Productivity Commission to be a specific reference body, not a general body. The legislation should ensure that all references which have been referred to the commission are included in the annual report.

If the commission wishes to put other matters in the annual report, that is a decision for the commission to make. If the Productivity Commission wishes to include data on productivity or any other matter, that is up to the commission, and it should not be prescribed in legislation. I think it is a quite reasonable and sensible improvement, and I do not intend to make a lengthy contribution in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment, in our view, narrows the role of the Productivity Commission back to its reporting function. We think that is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not really recognise the ideologies of the Productivity Commission as resulting in expertise on Australia's general economy. TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens (WA) will support this amendment.

—Could the minister advise the committee as to whether, in the government's view, the amendment by Senator Sherry—which seems to be quite reasonable—would preclude the commission from reporting in its annual report on the productivity performance of industry and of the economy as a whole, and on the principal factors affecting that performance? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes that it would narrow the scope of the clause to `development of industry'. You would then read productivity as more narrowly defined. What I will propose, as I did earlier with a previous clause, is simply to include the word `industry' before the words `industry development and productivity'. The coalition would be happy to live with the Labor proposal with the addition of that word. Therefore, in respect of Senator Sherry's amendment No. 1, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit `industry development', substitute `industry, industry development'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Campbell's amend ment to Senator Sherry's proposed amendment No. 1 be agreed to.
—The question now is that Senator Sherry's amendment No. 1, as amended, and amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 11, page 8 (lines 25 to 28), omit subclause (4), substitute:
(4) If the Minister refers a matter to the Commission for inquiry, the Commission may also make recommendations in the report on any matters relevant to the matter referred.
Under part 3 of the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 , subclause 11(4) states:
If the Minister refers a matter to the Commission for inquiry, the Commission may also inquire into and make recommendations in the report on any matters it considers relevant to the matter referred.

Our amendment clarifies the extent of the commission's discretion concerning references for inquiry from the minister. Our amendment tightens up subclause 11(4), which we consider to be too wide. The discretion for the commission to inquire into any matters it considers relevant concerning references in subclause (4) is too broad. As currently drafted, the provision allows the commission to report on any matter, even those which, on an objective test, have nothing to do with a reference from the minister.

The amendment seeks to impose an objective test on the relevance of the matters to be reported on and to remove the commission's powers of inquiry on these other issues. The commission will be able to make recommendations about these issues. It will then properly be within the power of the minister to determine whether or not an inquiry should be held on the issues.

Under subclause 11(4), if the minister refers a matter to the commission for inquiry, the commission may also make recommendations and report on any matters relevant to the matter referred. That is a major change of emphasis. We do not believe the commission should be allowed the unrestrained approach that it could take. It should act within the parameters of the guidelines that are set down for an inquiry. It should not go beyond those parameters and act in the way that it considers is relevant. We do not believe that the extensive nature of this power is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL

I rise tonight to speak to the Western Australian Fisheries Joint Authority report of July 1995 to 30 June 1996. Two areas are dealt with by the joint authority: the southern demersal gillnet and demersal long line managed fishery; and the joint authority northern shark fishery.

The response from the southern demersal gillnet and demersal long line managed fisheries are of concern. The fishery that I just mentioned deals with the stocks of whiskery, gummy and bronzed whaler sharks, and the report on page 4 clearly indicates that those sharks are overexploited. The stock assessment and projections of future catch indicate that whiskery shark stocks are at about 24 per cent of their original biomass, and significant effort reductions are required to ensure their long-term viability.

Gummy shark stocks are at about 45 per cent of their original biomass, with a continuing downward trend without significant effort reductions. Bronze whaler stocks are at approximately 65 per cent of their original biomass. Effort reductions, they suggest, are required in the joint authority; that is the catch.

The joint authority for the northern shark fishery includes the area which straddles the north of Australia and parts of the Northern Territory. That is important because that is also an area which goes to the current outer limit of Australia's fishing zone. I will mention that in a little while. Page 7 of the report on the condition of the fishery says:
There is little data upon which an accurate assessment of the stock could be based. However, domestic catch rates indicate that the fishery's biomass is below a sustainable level.

So in two areas quite apart from each other the indications are that the fishery is unsustainable. In relation to the research from the joint northern shark fishery, the sources come from the Taiwanese gill net fishery, catch and effort data from domestic operators and a CSIRO study coordinating the then Commonwealth department of primary industries and the state fisheries departments of Western Australia, Northern Territory and Queensland.

I think many people are recognising that, as an industry and as a set of ecosystems, we have to be very careful about the way we manage fisheries and marine resources because they are not inexhaustible. It does ring warning bells in terms of other species, what is happening to those species, what Australia is doing in terms of agreements with other countries on catches and about the way we manage fishing stocks ourselves. There is still a lot of work to be done on fishing, resources, where breeding areas are and what we should be doing to make sure that that is a sustainable resource and that the ecosystem is sustainable. What are we going to do when we do not have fish any more?

BREAK.PARA: I want to mention the northern shark fishery in particular. Whilst the warning bells are ringing there in terms of its unsustainability, that may well change for the worse because Australia has signed a joint seabed agreement with Indonesia. That is up for ratification at the moment. There will be an inquiry in relation to the bilateral treaty on seabed boundaries and I urge all those people interested in Australia's sustainable fishery and marine resources to look at the implications of the agreement between Australia and Indonesia which will mean that Australia's joint seabed will be different from what it is now. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I welcome this discussion paper entitled `Delivery of Primary Dispute Resolution Services in Family Law—August 1997', which has been presented to the parliament today by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). I congratulate him on this initiative. It is the culmination of some degree of work by the Attorney and his department after his initial address on this issue to the National Press Club on 15 October last year. In that address he expressed his keenness to maximise access to primary forms of dispute resolution, or what is normally known as alternative dispute resolution, such as mediation and counselling.

The area of family law, it would be fair to say, is one that is always enveloped in a degree of emotion and personal devastation and where the practitioners involved are often dealing with the rawest of human emotions. Therefore, it is desirable to try to provide mechanisms for people to deal with those conflicts and difficulties within their lives out of the combative regime of the Family Court system and suggest that they go to other fora to explore the possibility of settlement and a dispute resolution between them.

This document, which has been put before us by the Attorney‐General, basically canvasses a whole range of issues without coming to any final conclusions and in fact invites comments and submissions from our fellow Australians to have an input into this very important area of social concern. The closing date for submissions is 28 November 1997, so there is a good three‐month period in which people can make submissions. They can be sent to the Assistant Secretary, Courts, Tribunals and Administrative Law Branch, Attorney‐General's Department, Robert Garran Offices, National Circuit, Barton, ACT 2600.

In chapter 2 of the discussion paper the Attorney‐General deals with objectives for an improved structure. I think it is appropriate to quickly canvass the four major points that are highlighted as being necessary for such an improved structure. It reads:

The principal objectives for any reformed structure for the delivery of services to people dealing with relationship breakdown are essentially fourfold. Firstly, the structure should offer the greatest opportunity and encouragement for people to resolve their family disputes without recourse to litigation; secondly, services should focus on the needs of clients and provide equity of access; thirdly, service provisions should be opened up to a wide field of providers if this will ensure the delivery of higher quality and more flexible services; and, fourthly, expenditure of public funds on primary dispute resolution should be accountable to ensure high quality for clients and value for dollars spent.

I welcome the discussion in this paper of those four objectives and also the discussion of the importance of client focus in this very important area. Can I simply say that those of us who do spend time listening to and talking to the electorate would know that this area of alternative dispute resolution in family law matters is one that is of great interest to the general public and, might I say, in relation to some of the discussions we have had in recent times, somewhat more prioritised in the community's mind than privacy, cross‐media ownership or issues of that nature. I conclude by congratulating the Attorney‐General on this excellent initiative. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
