TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to seek the incorporation of a letter into the Hansard . The letter is written by Martin Williams and involves the death of his wife, Esther Wild, who died on 17 April this year. All honourable senators who participated—as we all did—in the euthanasia debate here in this chamber would know both of those names.

SPEECH.PARA: Esther Wild was the patient who had asked for euthanasia from Dr Nitschke and she was the patient who was not able to have euthanasia administered by Dr Nitschke because of the vote taken here in the Senate. Martin Williams, a man whom I respect enormously, is a typical Australian working man—a decent bloke, devoted absolutely to his partner and a man who suffered enormously, as she did, in the last days of her life. She, as I said, wanted to avail herself of the euthanasia machine of Dr Nitschke and could not do so. Of course, this was all highly publicised at the time. Dr Nitschke administered to Esther Wild over a period of some four days a series of drugs which kept her in a largely comatose state, although she revived, unplanned, on a number of occasions and finally died after four days. This point is made in the letter.

The administration of these drugs over that period of four days appears to have been perfectly legal. Certainly no action has been taken against Dr Nitschke and, indeed, public statements by Kevin Andrews and other doctors at the time indicated that the administration of drugs in this fashion was, in fact, legal and, indeed, moral. But the administration of such drugs over a period of an hour, for example, or even 10 minutes, was not—which is the point made in the letter.

One thing I do want to make clear is that the incorporation of this letter tonight has nothing whatever to do with the recent Northern Territory election. Indeed, Senator Tambling and I agreed publicly that euthanasia had little or no effect on the result—which is what I believe, despite the fact that it was raised during the campaign.

BREAK.PARA: The reason the letter is being tabled quite simply is this: Martin Williams came to see me after the death of his wife and asked me whether I would be prepared to present to this Senate a personal message from him regarding the death of his wife. I said—as I would to any other constituent of mine in the Northern Territory—that, providing it was in accordance with standing orders and proprieties of this chamber, I would be happy to do so. Martin Williams is well aware that I do not share his position on this issue. But, as I said during the debate itself, although I do not agree, I absolutely respect his position on this, and it would be utterly presumptuous of me to even pretend that I would understand completely what he and his wife went through.

When you read this letter you will see why I am seeking to have it incorporated. Frankly, the reason is that I do not feel it appropriate for me to read it into the Hansard: it is an intensely personal letter. Can I say, for the advice of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), who is at the table, that I did seek permission from the government whip, who read the letter prior to the debate, and that permission has been given. I seek leave to have Mr Williams's letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
20th August, 1997.
The Hon. John Howard, MP,
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Howard,
To the Senators who voted in favour of the Andrews Bill and therefore became deeply involved in the manner in which Esther Wild passed away on 17/4/97.

Following her plea for mercy. For almost 2 months her former workmates instituted a roster to enable their fellow work-mate in need to stay in the environment she loved so much to pass on with some idea of peace in her own home. These peoples love and practical devotion to their fellow worker and friend can not be measured on earth.
They sacrificed their own time and family time to cause for Esther as true friends, Territorians and Australians.
During this time, continuous pain was ever present, with regular colostomy failure causing minimum sleep for both Esther and her carers.
I must thank you all your loving care, support and humane concern.

Ester's body had been declining rapidly The lower body was a large oedema, due to lymph gland failure. During the past months, towels were placed in her bed and under her feet while sitting. This was to soak up the fluid leaching through her skin in the lower legs.

The suture line from the colostomy operation had a drainage tube placed in it. It healed and then allowed a volume of puss and fluid to build up to a point where it began to weep from the dis-used bowel and internal wounds.
The pressure built up so immensely that it finally burst one night under the shower.
This discharge, a purulent smelly puss continued for the remainder of her days. It caused her extreme personal distress and was also present in other orifices on her body.
Please explain to me "The Sanctity of Life" that the Senators find so precious and how the Senators identify the N.T.'s Rights of the Terminally Ill Act as a licence to commit murder.
How indecent can one become to promote the ideology that to suffer is to gain assent to heavenly peace?
It is with many tears I write the above, and with many more the following.
Easter 97 .
Esther's mates worked the night roster and I did the day shift, with the assistance and direction of the NT Community Health Services.
Easter Saturday: A day I will remember.
8.30am. Esther was sitting up on the bed's edge (semi non-compos mentis) and said:
"My bag's burst, lovie".
Okay, I'll help you, as I have before."
And this is what I did:

I placed my hands under her arms to pick her up and carry her to the bathroom, she was unable to stand or support herself, I then had to carry her back to her soiled bed on excrement and use an absorption towel, I had a phone call from one of her Workmates before this, so I knew that she and a weekend nurse would be there soon. I felt somewhat helpless myself.
3pm: Sameday.
Same problem. The community nurse worked unto 6pm, unpaid, to help a mate in trouble.

Next, Esther felt the desire to vomit and requested a bucket. We stood rotating two buckets, one to be sick in and then change to a clean bucket. This continued for at least 2 hours. The vomiting became involuntary and unstoppable. Drugs were injected and a wavering between oblivion and sleep occurred.

A drug induced coma was achieved to Esther's benefit, since euthanasia was now only available by way of double effect or slow euthanasia, although the Senate would deny this as any form of euthanasia but a proper procedure of palliative care. In other words a sadistic alternative that satisfied the right wing Christian lobby—perhaps to their heavenly required, certainly no clear benefit to any patient on earth.
At the termination of the NT's Rights of fee Terminally Ill Act. The Andrew's Bill approved the double effect syndrome.
Esther was familiar with this routine, due to her lifetime career in the nursing profession, and at that stage rejected it having witnessed similar deaths and their effects on the close loved ones.
Easter passed and Esther came around. She asked for respite at the Darwin Private Hospital to give us all a break. It was a much appreciated spell.

Ester was now ready to come Some. She was ready to die and wished to be in her own home in her final days. She now asked for the hypercritical drug induced coma to be commenced. (Refer to Four Corners Program: THE DYING GAME).
Her personal intention was to die as quickly as possible with this procedure. Her primary intention was to die as the pain could not be controlled any other way.
Sunday 14th April, 1997
The process commenced today at 12 noon. The drugs added to the morphine should have created a comatosed situation for 4—6 hours.
2pm.
A former workmate of Esther's arrived and Esther awoke from her coma. She asked for a smoke. She smoked a couple of smokes and then requested the procedure to continue.
2pm—5pm.
During this time Esther woke again, had several smokes and a sip of ice-water. She then requested continuance of the coma.
9pm.
Another visitor arrived. Esther awoke again she had a conversation with those present. She asked for her cigarettes and some ice-water. I placed a token nip of whisky in her ice-water.
"I put some whisky in there for you mate", I said.
"Thanks", she replied.
She took 2 sips of her whisky and finished her smoke and then for the fourth time, she said her good-byes to all her friends and said, "I love you".

Each time she woke during this 9 hour period she asked to die. She could not die how she wanted, but now had to use the accepted sacred system that was forced upon her by the voting of the Andrew's Bill.
I held that woman four times while she passed out.
No human should have to put up with this torture in the name of so called Christianity.
That torture was inflicted on Esther by 38 Senators.
Esther warned me before the coma began that the final senses of a person in a comatosed state is the hearing and to be careful how one should speak in her presence.
As we moved her body to change the bed linen, she would cry out in pain although comatosed or unable to open her eyes.
On the third day she opened her eyes and asked a longstanding mate "Tell me truly Cathy am I really dead?" She then passed back into oblivion.
11pm that night Esther died.
Finally after almost 7 years on morphine and other drugs. Death became precious and pain free.
You in the Senate who voted as you did, inflicted the final torture on a beautiful, caring lady.
You did this by:
1. Voting against the exemption or delaying to allow her and one other to access a merciful death.
2. The repeal of one of the most merciful pieces of legislation, allowing the freedom to choose and only for those whom wish to partake.
So now I ask if each of you is totally at peace within yourselves. Stand up and be counted as proud honourable people. If your vote could be called honourable.

Or sit in silent shame for the symbolic, debauchery the Andrew's Bill meant to Esther's body and spirit, and all those unfortunate enough to need and wish for a merciful exit, through a quirk of nature, which they have no control of.

I ask "Please redeem yourselves if you have a conscience, have this evil bill repealed. That way you can forever look any person straight in the eye and say "I am a Christian humanitarian and believe in personal freedom with only one ultimate Judge and not that of an elected Senate".

If you feel you have done the right thing then I challenge any one of you to openly debate the sanctity of life and death and the motives you may have had in sentencing a weak person unable to fight back to death in this way on national TV.
I also solemnly promise, should I have breath in my body to publish this letter in each and every one of your electorates concerned at the next election.
Yours sincerely,
MARTIN WILLIAMS.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to one of the people in this parliament who has been part of the behind‐the‐scenes theatre of the parliament. Often, when we see members of parliament, we forget that behind the scenes is the army of people in the Table Office and Hansard, all the people who maintain the infrastructure of this building and those people who offer us advice. Tonight, it is Professor Douglas Whalan to whom I want to pay tribute. Professor Whalan has announced his retirement and I want to take this opportunity because his retirement took effect as of 31 August.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to say a little about the committee on which Professor Whalan mainly served, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. He did spend some time on the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The regulations and ordinances committee, of which Senator Collins was once chairman and of which I have been a member for some considerable period of time, is a committee like none other in the parliament. It is a special committee. People go on it and stay on it for a very long while. I think it is one of the most interesting committees in parliament. It has been copied in other Westminster parliaments because it protects the rights of individuals.

The committee was set up in 1932 when academics and politicians felt that regulations and other subordinate legislation was not being properly scrutinised. It has a long and proud tradition of protecting the rights of individuals, and it has never ever lost when it has moved a disallowance of a motion. It is one of the most careful committees, but it relies enormously on the legal advice that it gets.

Professor Douglas Whalan has been legal adviser to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for about 15 years and one month. He was born in New Zealand. He was a barrister and solicitor of the high courts of Australia and New Zealand and the Supreme Court of the ACT. Professor Whalan was also dean of the Faculty of Law and chairman of the academic board of the Australian National University. On retiring early, he was appointed emeritus professor at the Australian National University.

Professor Whalan has been the independent legal adviser to the committee since August 1982 and was the acting legal adviser to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills for 13 months during 1989-91. He also prepared special reports for the committee, he gave other advice and, when required, attended meetings of the committee. In fact, he attended most of the meetings in the last few years that I have been a member. I was also a member in the first three years of my parliamentary career, and he attended meetings then. He has also advised the Australian Capital Territory Scrutiny of Bills and Subordinate Legislation Committee.

He was awarded an Order of Australia in the Australia Day honours list in 1994. One of the reasons he received that award was for his contribution to this parliament through his advice. I remember with great fondness when he was the token male, as he called himself, when a delegation went to what I think was the third Commonwealth delegated legislation conference in London. The delegation was made up of former Senator Giles, former Senator Bronwyn Bishop, Senator Crowley, me, Anne Lynch, the deputy clerk, and Professor Whalan as our adviser. We thought he was particularly game coming to London with all of us. We had some enormous fun at the meetings and also after the meetings. I remember one particularly wonderful night when we sat in a London pub and entertained a number of people with our Australian stories.

I also have to remark upon the diligence that Professor Whalan has applied. He has been assiduous in applying attention to detail. We estimated that he has produced 771 reports and he has read and dealt with about 18,000 instruments, regulations, determinations, ordinances, plans of management and a plethora of other delegated legislated instruments. Some of them are inches high and incredibly boring. He has written these reports in enormous detail. Not one single thing would have slipped through his attention to that detail in protecting the rights of people, to make sure there is not a reversal of onus of proof and to ensure that people's rights have not been infringed.

The advice we have been given and received has been enormously welcomed and valued and ought to be recognised by all the Australian people because at some stage every single person in this country is affected by a piece of subordinate legislation. It is because of Douglas Whalan's diligence and because of his attention to detail that they are most probably less likely to be caught up in unintended consequences of that legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have drawn attention to the enormous job losses this country has suffered as a direct result of the decisions of this government since they came to office. As the Senate will be aware, the Democrats gave notice yesterday of an inquiry we would like to see into the impact of public sector job losses on regions. We know, for instance, that COSBOA recently reported that in Cooma in New South Wales 361 jobs were lost from the public sector. Those job losses resulted in 180 families moving out of the area and $11.8 million also going from the region. I travel around the country on a regular basis and hear stories about the declining economies of small, medium and large towns.

SPEECH.PARA: I would argue that Australians are crying out for something to be done about the loss of jobs, which appears in many communities to be simply unstoppable. Whether it is the closure of banks, state or local government agencies closing down, Commonwealth services going, or simply a result of the obsession that both governments and the private sector seem to have with downsizing or offshore manufacturing or contracting out government services to large overseas companies, the feeling is that this has taken over our entire country.

I want to talk tonight about the fact that our government seems to be trotting along obediently behind multinational consultants and accountancy firms and appears to be doing their every bidding. We are getting down to core business; we are steering not rowing; we are shedding ourselves of staff whose work could possibly be done from outside government.

The arbitrary decision by the government to tender out IT services of every government agency and the arbitrary way in which budget cuts to those agencies assumed a very consistent level of saving was made regardless of the impacts on service or even any real or reliable data on the likelihood of those savings actually being achieved. There is much that will be said in this place about IT outsourcing. As the Senate will be aware, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is currently inquiring into this very issue.

The matter I want to deal with tonight is the total lack of interest of this government in seeing that Australia's IT companies have a fighting chance to compete in what is going on here at present. It seems to me that the government has been led down the path of competitive neutrality and into that realm of global inevitability—the inevitability of multinationals dominating forever computer technology and the inevitability that Australia will not and cannot be part of that scene.

Senator Murray, during estimates last month, went to some lengths to press the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) and departmental heads on the matter of government contracts in the IT area and opportunities afforded to Australian companies. He asked whether, all things being equal in the tenders, the federal government would be biased towards awarding the contract to an Australian company rather than one from overseas.

I would argue that a few years ago, in perhaps more enlightened times, such a question would have been answered with some enthusiasm to the effect that policy was to support local industry. But not so now. Minister Kemp informed the committee:

. . . the government's goal is to encourage and expand Australian and New Zealand industry's role in the global environment by promoting a competitive domestic environment for businesses and, in doing this, agencies should recognise, in assessing value for money and whole of life costs, the commercial and practical advantages of doing business with competitive Australian and New Zealand industry.
It is a bit of doubletalk, but I think what that means is that we will make things competitive at home and just hope for the best. The government, he said, would:
. . . investigate Australian and New Zealand industry capability to provide fair opportunity for suppliers to compete.
This does not seem to me to be very strong encouragement for Australian industry. Mr Godfrey, in response to the `all things being equal' question, said:

I would not be biased towards any tenderer in the evaluation of a tender document. We would have to consider whether there was some way of separating them, and the overall effect of the Commonwealth might then tip the advantage towards the Australian firm.
Might, I stress. When asked whether or not it mattered to the government whether it is an Australian or a foreign company, Mr Godfrey said:

I think the process for evaluation of procurements is established on value for money. If it is not listed as one of those evaluation criteria, you have to divorce any personal views from that evaluation.

In this current climate, let us look at the issue which came to the attention of the Senate today and which was reported in the Financial Review yesterday. The issue is about PC suppliers and the difficulty Australian PC suppliers are having in competing.

I use as an example Ipex. Ipex is a 100 per cent Australian owned information technology company, and it employs 320 people in Australia and another 170 in Israel, Germany, Ireland, Thailand and New Zealand. It is not an enormous organisation but it is a growing one. It is not a multinational in the normal sense of the word but it certainly is one which is expanding beyond our shores and making itself into a global player.

This company was started in 1982 and, as I understand it, has returned a profit every year since its inception. It has no debt and it runs on cash flow. All elements of research and development, quality control and product support are undertaken locally—here in Australia. In 1996, Ipex was the third largest PC and server supplier in Australia. Ipex supplies only the corporate and government marketplace and, I am told, it has been the largest supplier to Australia's marketplace over the last four years.

The issue here is that Ipex does not qualify as a PC supplier in the specification drawn up by the Australian Customs Service for IT services. The specification operates on a model drawn up by the Gartner Group, a multinational consultant organisation, and it requires that a supplier should produce a minimum of 250,000 units per annum. The model requires organisations to comply with a number of metrics—finance performance, product reliability, quality control and formal review processes—and what are known as tier 1 and tier 2 include this minimum number of units. The minimum number was developed in the US, which is of course reaching an enormous market compared with that in Australia.

The number of units is the amount which Gartner would argue is the minimum required to gain the leverage to produce quality consistent product. But of course the problem is that the model considers only supply of product worldwide or in major regions such as in Europe. It does not consider smaller regions or specific countries. The weakness in this model is that it is essentially an American model. It does not take into account regional diversity, regional requirements or regional strengths of local manufacturers.

They would say the model should be used in conjunction with local requirements, market share and strength of local vendors. The problem is that here in Australia departments such as the Australian Customs Service are not doing so and the effect is that the model is being used to prevent local vendors from even taking part in the tendering process.

BREAK.PARA: There is a clause in the specification for the ASC which allows for another industry, and that could be approved by a contract manager. But in this case no contract manager was ever appointed and there was no opportunity to change this minimum requirement.

The government might argue that the purpose of the model is to minimise the risk to organisations when making purchases, but that is not in fact reflected in some of the recent occurrences with overseas organisations. I have a long list of those organisations that have failed to supply PCs and other equipment in a consistent manner.

The industry argues that, if this kind of approach to IT were used in, say, the banking industry, it would produce quite ridiculous results. It would mean that in this country the government would not be able to deal with our local banks and it would have to use overseas organisations.

I will finish quickly by saying that the industry is calling for a number of factors. It wants to see any supplier being able to produce, financial stability, market presence, local expertise, previous experience, industry initiatives and development, export potential, and quality of products and services. Those seem to me to be very worthwhile measures that ought to be replaced by the sorts of arrangements that we currently have which clearly discriminate against our local suppliers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Newcastle and the Hunter Region: Job Losses

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in this debate to make a progress report to the Senate on the plans of the federal government for Newcastle and the Hunter region following the announcement by BHP to downsize its steel making operations in that city. This will lead to the loss of 2,500 direct jobs within the next two years and over 1,000 additional contract positions, with an estimated flow‐on effect of a further 3,000 jobs. To give the Senate an example of the impact of this on one area, in the city of Lake Macquarie there are likely to be over 900 displaced workers and their families resulting from this announcement.

BREAK.PARA: At the same time, the decision by BHP to cease steel making in Newcastle has given this region a priority in terms of the national interest. Quite appropriately, the people of the region have looked to the federal government for leadership and direction in relation to the future of the region as it refashions its economic base.

I am delighted to report to the Senate that the Howard government has provided and continues to provide leadership to Newcastle and the Hunter region. On 16 and 17 July this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made a highly publicised trip to Newcastle and the Hunter. The two-day visit focused the nation's attention on the current plight of this region, and John Howard used the authority of his prime ministership to wipe out the national perception that this decision by BHP had crippled the region.

Having identified Newcastle with steel for so long, people probably do not realise how enormously diverse the economy of Newcastle is with, for example, its equine industry and the horse studs in the Upper Hunter—we have more of those than the Kentucky bluegrass country—and the winery industry. It has the best wine growing region in Australia.
Senator Heffernan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting some conflict on this view from one of my colleagues, but in the Hunter we will claim that. Certainly the recreational areas of Port Stephens and Lake Macquarie have so much to offer.

BREAK.PARA: What people do not often realise is that BHP is not really the biggest employer in Newcastle; it is actually the Hunter Area Health Service, followed by education, BHP and a very wide range of wholesale and retail outlets. The city and the region employ 70 per cent of its work force in the services industry. I just say that to put this problem, which is indeed a major one, in perspective. If you lose that many jobs out of any region, it is a major problem. I just point out to the Senate the resilient nature of the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister prepared to do something about it in every Australian region?

—He certainly has done a lot about it and I am just about to point out what he has done, unlike the former Labor government, which did absolutely nothing when BHP made this announcement during its term, and I cannot recall its local members of parliament saying boo about it at the time. Where was the second steel plan, for example? Nothing like that was proposed in 1995.
—Is the government prepared to take the same attitude to other regions where it has been responsible for the decline in jobs, as has happened in the nation's capital?

—You will find, Senator Lundy, that this government has taken leadership in this area and has shown what a Prime Minister's intense concern for a particular region can do, backed by a range of projects to back that region. Let us go back to your government—and I assume you are talking about things like the textile, clothing and footwear industries—and look at the absolute devastation it wreaked on these industries over a period of 15 years. It dropped tariffs from 105 per cent to 35 per cent over 13 years. There was absolutely massive downsizing in that area. We have shown through our decision on car tariffs that we are a little more sensitive than the last Labor government was and that is now reaping extra investment.
—I am pleased to hear you speak so strongly in support of the maintenance of tariffs.

—I am surprised you brought that up because John Howard showed during his visit on the 16th and the 17th that this government is prepared to focus on regions that are having difficulty, and he has signalled support in a wide range of industries in an area that has been developing a very broad‐based economy over the last 200 years. I would like to make the point to the Senate that last week Newcastle turned 200. There are not too many areas of Australia that have actually done that, and I think Sydney's is the only region. This is the second‐oldest region in Australia. It is a region that has experienced many hardships, like the earthquake in 1989 in which 12 people were killed and 32,000 buildings were damaged. But like that event, the earthquake created by BHP will be coped with by the people in the local region and they will come through that like they have come through many problems in the past.

BREAK.PARA: Just to show you how the city has turned things around in the last 50 years, if you look back to what the region had in 1947 it was at that time called the `dirtiest city in Australia'. It boasted no art gallery, university or conservatorium. The port was on the verge of closure due to the silting‐up of the harbour. But at this time of the city's bicentenary, many of these negatives have been turned around and it is now one of the cleanest industrial cities in the world.

It has the largest regional university in Australia with world renowned reputations in several disciplines, including medicine and engineering, and one of the largest graduate business schools in the country. It has many successful art galleries, a symphony orchestra, a professional theatre company and a conservatorium. It has—and this surprises many people—in terms of cargo bulk handling the second‐largest port in Australia, second only to Sydney. So, much has been achieved over the last 50 years up to the point of the bicentennial celebration last week.

Of course, the whole thing has been clouded by BHP's announcement. Certainly, even though BHP is ceasing steelmaking in the country, as the region faces its third century there are many opportunities for it to move forward. It is a great pity that the Labor Party, in its reaction to this closure, has not looked towards this forward looking vision for the Hunter—as exemplified by the announcements of the Howard government—but has tended to look back. It has wallowed in the past. It has called on BHP to continue steelmaking in Newcastle using grossly outdated plant and so losing millions of dollars each month. That certainly would not have worked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trying to justify the government's negligence in this regard is not going to get you very far, but I will look forward to the support packages for all the regions in Australia which are suffering under this government.

—Before you speak on this subject, Senator Lundy, I would suggest that perhaps you find yourself a bit of information so you know what you are talking about. Labor's backward looking approach has been rejected by the people of Newcastle. We had Jennie George and Kim Beazley come up to address a rally, and I would like to report to the Senate that, out of a city of 350,000 people and a region of half a million people, 500 people turned up—which I think is 0.001 per cent of the population—to listen to the solution that Jennie George and Kim Beazley had to offer, which was no solution at all. They were looking backwards. They dealt themselves totally out of the game and really had no vision for the future.
—It is interesting that your mark of success is a highly publicised statement to try to justify the arbitrary decision by BHP to cut off jobs in regional areas.

—Senator Lundy, your opposition leader and colleagues were so ashamed of their approach that they have arranged a shadow cabinet meeting in Newcastle next week. Bob Baldwin and I actually found out about it by looking at the Internet. They had not announced it so we announced it for them to let people know that they were coming, and so encouraging people to talk to the Labor Party so at least they can have a reasonable policy for this city. John Howard and his government have already announced $19.5 million in expenditure for Newcastle. On top of that, in conjunction with the New South Wales government and with BHP, we are announcing another $25 million for specific projects to give this region a real boost. In addition to what we have announced, we are looking for two or three major projects that will help set this region in a new direction. We have actually created a new vision for Newcastle, and the Labor Party has no vision for Newcastle and the Hunter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday my eldest daughter, Maryann, died suddenly at the age of 37. Born with Down Syndrome, we suspect autistic, she never spoke. I speak of this tonight because I believe there is a need for the government and the community to understand the feelings of the families of the intellectually handicapped.

SPEECH.PARA: One of Maryann's sisters was overseas at the time of her death. She wrote a letter which summarises the feelings of her nine brothers and sisters:
Dear Mum and Dad,
Peter and I wanted to send you a note to let you know that we are thinking of you at the moment.

We could never imagine how difficult this is for you, but I guess that over here we have been able to cope so much better ourselves remembering how special Maryann really is, and how much she has helped all of us be such better people as a result of her just being. We feel so much for just being able to know her. On top of everything that both of you taught us, Maryann taught all of us patience, acceptance, and a fair amount of humility as well.

We feel so glad you had the opportunity to do Australian Story last year. We also feel an enormous gratitude to you both for speaking so freely about Maryann and exposing yourselves, and her, to everyone else who saw the programme. We were proud to have her as a sister, and proud that you were able to talk about everything so truthfully. People like Maryann so often spend their lives behind closed doors and without acceptance, and you diminished a lot of the stigma for people with the same disabilities, just by exposing our family as it is—we were privileged to have her as part of our family.
We can never fathom the depth of your grief, but we hope that you will have the time to grieve that you need.
We hope she has a beautiful good‐bye service, and we send our love with her.
With love,
Peter and Catriona
At the requiem mass, Father Jim Spence, a family friend, said the following:

In his book No Man is an Island Thomas Merton reminds us that we do not live more fully merely by doing more, seeing more, tasting more, experiencing more. What some of us need to discover is that we will not begin to live more fully until we have the courage to do and taste and see and experience much less.

Ultimately we are not judged on our material success in life. St Augustine reminds us: `In the evening of life we are judged on love.' We do not choose our talents, our handicaps, our temperaments. Rather, we are chosen to show aspects of God's love to the world, to help others grow towards the perfection of love.
A handicap is a reminder that no person is an island, that we need each other, that we need opportunities to serve each other.

We help each other even by giving people opportunities to serve us, to show love to us. Maryann is one of God's children who remained childlike—and Jesus reserved a special affection for children. He put his arms around them, laid his hands on them, and gave them his blessing. Our faith tells us that that is what he is doing with Maryann right now. Our hope assures us that `We shall all be reunited, when every tear will be wiped away.' Family and friends will be one again in God's kingdom.

So now we look not at what might have been but rather at what is to come. The hope of eternal glory is the comfort of our faith that brings shining through the sadness the confidence that death has not come to Maryann as a stranger, but as a friend, who took her by the hand and said:
`Arise, make haste my love, my dove, my beautiful one, and come.
The winter is over and gone;
The flowers have appeared in our land,
The time for singing has come.'

My wife and I are extremely grateful for the loving care and affection shown Maryann by the Sisters of Mercy and all the staff at the Mercy Centre over the years. She touched many people. We are also grateful for the condolences of our friends, my colleagues and fellow senators.

I particularly appreciate the action of Senator John Faulkner, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, who came to my office last Tuesday with a condolence card signed by opposition senators. John Faulkner had taught intellectually handicapped children in the past and was aware of the bond between the intellectually handicapped and their families.
My wife and I are strengthened by the knowledge that with Maryann's passing we have our own little saint in heaven who will watch over us forevermore.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: South Australian Government Youth Training Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the South Australian Government Youth Training Scheme.
(2) Has the scheme received Commonwealth funding; if so, how much.

(3) Was an approach made to the Minister's office or that of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs by any South Australian Minister for education and training about the expansion of the Youth Training Scheme in September 1996.
(4) Has the scheme been discontinued.
(5)What is, or was, the term of the scheme.
(6)How many young people are, and have, been involved in the scheme.
(7) Has the scheme been successful; if so, how has it been successful; if not, how has it failed.
(8) Is the Federal Government committed to continuing the scheme.
(9) Will the Federal Government continue to support the scheme; if so, for how long.
(10) Is the experience of the scheme useful to the Federal Government as a blue print for further youth training schemes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The South Australian Government Youth Training Scheme is an initiative established by the SA Government in 1993 to maximise the intake of young people into the South Australian public sector. The scheme aims to achieve a gender balance, participation of Aboriginal young people and an intake of school leavers and unemployed young people, on the basis that many would gain employment ultimately within the South Australian Government.

(2) The scheme has received significant Commonwealth funding in the past. From 1995/96 to 1996/97 the Commonwealth committed up to $9M to the scheme for the recruitment of 1500 trainees. The exact amount payable is not yet known as the funding period continues until the last trainee has completed his or her traineeship, which will be April 1998. In addition, the Commonwealth has recently agreed to provide up to $2.5M in 1997/98 for a further 500 commencements.2.

(3) An approach was made by the (then) Minister for Employment, Training and Further Education, the Hon Dr Bob Such, to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in October 1996 about the expansion of the scheme.

(5) According to the SA Office for the Commissioner for Public Employment (OCPE), the scheme is an ongoing initiative to increase the representation of young people in the South Australian public sector and to address training and employment issues for young people and has no specified term.

(6) The SA OCPE reports that, since its inception in December 1993, the scheme has resulted in employment and training positions for more than 4000 young people. The Federal Government has been involved in the scheme since February 1996 when the recruitment of 1500 young people into the SA public sector commenced, with many of those trainees still in training. A further 500 trainees are expected to be recruited from September 1997 to April 1998.

(7) The SA Office for the Commissioner for Public Employment considers the scheme to have been very successful. The SA OCPE considers it to be the single most significant initiative for youth training and employment through the South Australian Government which complements other State initiatives through the South Australian Department of Employment, Training and Further Education (DETAFE). The SA OCPE expects up to 80% of trainees recruited under the scheme to remain in employment at the completion of their training, either in the South Australian public sector or in the private sector.

(8) The Federal Government has agreed to assist the South Australian Government in respect of a further 500 trainees. Any further representation from the South Australian Government will be considered at the appropriate time.

(9) The Federal Government has agreed to support the scheme in respect of a further 500 trainees. The Commonwealth, through the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, has agreed to contribute up to $2.5M for this purpose.
(10) The experience of the scheme in South Australia is of interest to the Federal Government and may provide a basis for further projects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 1 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Earl Hill residential resort developments at Trinity Park, being developed by TNN Cairns Pty Ltd:
(1) What would be the Government's processes for preventing serious environmental harm if the Earl Hill project in Cairns, Queensland, was delayed or was not to proceed.
(2) Was an environmental impact study required for the Earl Hill project; if not, what was the rationale behind that decision.
(3) Is there a contingency plan in place to prevent environmental degradation due to delay, or lack or withdrawal of finances for the Earl Hill project.
(4) Does the Government plan to put in place any environmental controls on the project which are binding on foreign investors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume that the honourable Senator is referring to the proposal by TNN Cairns Pty Ltd for a residential resort and marina development north of Yorkey's Knob at Caims, Queensland.

Responsibility for the prevention of serious environmental harm for the proposal rests with local and State Government authorities. The Commonwealth has no jurisdiction over the site. Most of the development is to be located well outside the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area (GBRWHA), which extends to the low water mark. A small component comprising possible dredging of a marina entrance channel and possible dredge spoil disposal is proposed within the GBRWHA. While no permissions are required from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Authority has been consulted as part of the State assessment process.
I understand from media reports that the development has been "mothballed" for 12 months. No dredging or spoil disposal below the low water mark has occurred.

(2) Environmental impact assessments were undertaken by the local and State Governments in accordance with Queensland requirements at that time. Following an application for foreign investment by the proponent, the Foreign Investment Review Board designated Barrier Reef International Co Ltd as proponent for the proposal in accordance with the Administrative Procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

I am advised that the then Minister for the Environment determined on 16 June 1995 that there was no requirement for a Commonwealth Environmental Impact Statement or a Public Environment Report. This was in view of assessment action undertaken by Queensland authorities. The Minister made recommendations to the then Assistant Treasurer on measures for environmental protection, including requirements for monitoring and reporting, control of acid sulphate soils, water quality control measures and measures to protect conservation values.
(3) See my answer to (1) above.
(4) Foreign investors are required to comply with the recommendations for environmental protection that attach to the foreign investment approval.
